What's the most inaccurate thing your child has ever been taught in school? I picked up my daughter Zoe from school Tuesday afternoon, and when I leaned over to kiss her forehead like I always did, she jerked away. Don't, dad. Miss Novak taught us that when you get kissed, the person's DNA stays inside you for seven years, like you're infected. She said, we're collecting other people's gross stuff and can't ever get it out. Her eyes welled up. Mom kissed me goodbye this morning. Does that mean I have her gross DNA stuck in me now? My hands tightened on the steering wheel. I teach AP biology at the high school across town. And not only was this scientifically false, it was psychologically damaging. That evening, I sent Miss Novak a polite email explaining that I was Zoe's father and a biology teacher, and that DNA from saliva breaks down within hours, not years. Her reply came quickly. Mr. Coleman, it was a simple lesson on DNA and germs. You know, how kids can traumatize things. Wouldn't worry about it. I tried to brush it off, figuring maybe she just misspoken or Zoe had misunderstood. But then Wednesday morning, Zoe refused breakfast, and when I asked why, she pushed her bowl away and said, yesterday Miss Novak was crying in class. She kept talking about this guy she used to date, like, three years ago. She said she can still feel his gross DNA inside her from when They kissed him and she called him a walking contamination or something. I nearly choked on my coffee. She's discussing her ex boyfriend with 12 year olds. Zoe nodded miserably. She was actually crying, dad. She said guys like Brad just want to infect girls with their DNA and then leave them. It was really weird. By Thursday, the parent group chat explode. Multiple children had come home terrified of physical contact. One mother wrote that her daughter wouldn't hug her uncle anymore because Miss Novak said men spread more DNA than women. Another parent said their son was dehydrated because he refused to use the water fountain after Miss Novak said drinking from it was basically like kissing everyone who used it before you, collecting years of their DNA in your mouth. First thing Friday morning, I met with Prince Vazquez alongside three other concerned parents. We presented our concerns about Miss Novak, discussing her personal dating life and teaching false science. The principal reviewed her file and found two previous complaints.

What petty sibling fight backfired so badly your family doesn't talk about it? My sister Gwen told mom I was a domestic terrorist for taking 20 minute showers before school. And mom believed her. Gwen used to be cool when we were younger. We'd stay up watching movies and she'd sneak me candy when mom said no more sugar. But she turned into a huge jerk when she came back home from her first semester of college. She start acting like a house was her personal hotel and everyone else was just in her way. First it was the TV. She changed all the streaming passwords so only she could log in. Even told our twelve year old brother to grow up when he wanted to watch cartoons on Saturday morning while she binged Love Island all day. Now, apparently, my bathroom was her territory, too. I tried to be considerate, I really did. I'd set my alarm 10 minutes earlier so I could be done before she woke up. I kept my shampoo and stuff in a basket so everything was clean and organized and she wanted to use it. And still she complained. Gwen told our parents I was hogging the bathroom every morning, even though I showered an hour before she woke up. She complained that the steam from my hot showers made the bathroom more moldy and toxic and gave her asthma. But it was summer, so I only took cold showers. Mom scolded me, telling Me to be more considerate of my sister. But that only made her lies older. She started setting her alarm for 6:00am just to me in the bathroom. Then she'd tell our parents I woke her up. So mom scolded me again, texting, be quieter next time. Your sister needs sleep. The lie that really got me into trouble was when Gwen claimed she lost her dream job at a marketing firm because I hogged the bathroom that morning. I finished my shower when I heard her phone blaring job interview today over and over. But Gwen was dead asleep. Now, I could have let her miss it, you know, especially after everything she done. But I still tried to wake her up. I shook her shoulders, turned on the lights, even pulled off her blankets. Nothing worked. When she finally did wake up, she had 20 minutes to get to her interview. She came home sobbing, mascara running down her

How I exposed my mother in law's custody conspiracy. Three months after my wife died from cancer, my mother in law started going after me. She'd been staying with us to help with my nine year old daughter, Megan. And at first I was thankful, but then. And Megan came to me, twisting her hands together and said, daddy, why does grandma keep asking when we're selling the house and moving somewhere cheap? That should have been my warning sign. The real trouble began when she called CPS herself, telling them I was neglecting Megan and leaving her home alone while I slept all day from depression. The case worker, Miss Lane, showed up with her clipboard already out and her pen clicking. And two days later, my mother in law filed for emergency custody. I tried explaining I work from home, but Lane just kept her eyes on her notepad, scribbling away. And my chest got tight watching her write down whatever story she'd already decided was true. My lawyer, Tom, was the only one who believed my side of things. When I brought him the custody papers, I watched his eyebrows shoot up as he spread them across his mahogany desk, pointing to different sections where my mother in law had brought up the life insurance trust fund three times in documents that were supposed to be about Megan safety. Why would she keep mentioning money and papers about keeping Megan safe? Tom tapped the papers with his Pen and said we needed to look deeper into her motivations. That's when pieces started falling into place. Bought a leather journal and started tracking everything. After Miss UNT. Lane's second surprise visit, the pattern was obvious. Once I started writing it down. Lane would show up unannounced with her clipboard, and somehow my mother in law's silver car would appear within minutes. Every single time, she'd step out with her hand pressed over her heart. Playing the worried grandmother perfectly. Tom's investigator changed everything when he slid that Manila folder across the desk. My mother in law owed $200,000 in tax liens. The dates made my stomach drop. Filed just two months before

Dad moves in, soon to be bride gets pregnant, and she demands I leave the house because she needs my room. I'm 19, working at target during the day and delivering pizzas at night just to afford community college. Dad moved in with his girlfriend Nicole three months ago after losing his apartment when he got fired. The arrangement was supposed to be temporary, just until I get back on my feet, he promised. That was 12 weeks ago, and he spent most of his time on my couch watching Netflix. Yesterday, Nicole storms into my room while I'm trying to study for my accounting midterm. She's got that entitled look she gets when she's about to make unreasonable demands. We need to talk about your living situation. I looked up from my textbook my living situation. With the baby coming in six months, we're going to need your room for the nursery. You're young and flexible. You can sleep anywhere. I stared at her. This woman who contributes exactly zero dollars to household expenses was trying to kick me out of my own bedroom. This is my room, Nicole. She crossed her arms. Not anymore. Your father and I discussed it, and we've decided you can use the garage. We'll get you a space heater for winter. I actually laughed out loud. The garage? Are you completely insane? Don't be dramatic, Lucas. Lots of college kids would love a free place to stay. You should be grateful. Free place? To stay? That's rich, coming from someone who hasn't paid a dime toward anything. That's when inspiration hit me. I pulled out my phone and scrolled to my landlord's number. What are you doing? Nicole asked nervously. I hit dial and put it on speaker. Hi, Mrs. Davis, it's Lucas. Quick question. Whose name is on the lease for this house? Nicole's eyes went wide as she realized what was happening. Just yours, Lucas, like we discussed when you signed it six months ago. Why? Is there a problem? No problem. And who pays the rent every month

I overheard my girlfriend say, he's going to propose tonight. Watch me say no and make him cry. I still took her to the rooftop, got down on one knee, then pulled out her texts with her gym buddy and said loudly, actually, I'm not proposing. I'm here to say goodbye. In front of everyone you tried to impress? This happened three weeks ago, and I'm still processing it. My girlfriend Danielle and I had been together for three years. She's been dropping engagement hints constantly, showing me rings, talking about weddings I've been secretly saving for months. Even picked out a ring. The plan was to propose at her company's rooftop holiday party. Kept mentioning how romantic it would be with the city lights and all her co workers there. But last Tuesday changed everything. I came home early from my hospital shift. I heard Danielle on Facetime upstairs, laughing. Melissa, he's definitely doing it at the party tomorrow. He's been acting all secretive. I stopped on the stairs. That's exciting. Are you ready? Her sister asked. Here's the thing. I'm saying no right in front of everyone. My blood went cold. Danielle. What? Why? He needs a reality check. Plus, you know Anthony from Crossfit? He just started his own business. Way more ambitious than a nurse. Anthony? The guy she'd been training with three nights a week? You're really going to humiliate him at your work party? Picture this. All my co workers watching. He gets down, On one knee. And I just say, sorry, but no. Maybe he'll understand. He can't coast through life helping sick people all day. They both giggled. I quietly went to my car and sat there for an hour. That night. Danielle was all over me. Babe, I love you so much. All I could think about was her planning my destruction. Wednesday morning, her phone buzzed with a text from Anthony. Can't wait to celebrate tomorrow. She'd left it unlocked. I scrolled through their messages.

What's the easiest hundred dollars you've ever made in your life? This scrawny kid named Georgie slipped a hundred dollar Bill into my hand during lunch and told me it was mine if I beat up Carson Block. I almost spit out my chocolate milk. Carson was the biggest eighth grader anyone had ever seen. He looked like he spent time in prison and was pitching, not catching G, if you know what I mean. The kid was six feet tall with arms thicker than my legs. Meanwhile, Georgie was maybe 90 pounds, soaking wet, with these skinny arms that look like twigs. His left arm was in a homemade sling made from an old T-shirt. I stared at the money, thinking this had to be some kind of joke. Nobody in their right mind would pay someone to fight Carson. The kid had put three seventh graders in the nurse's office just this month. I'm pretty sure the security guards were scared of him. But Georgie's eyes were dead serious and kind of desperate. Why me? I asked. Because you're the only one who stands a chance. You knocked out that ninth grader last year who was messing with your sister. That was different, though. That kid had been picking on my little sister for weeks. This felt random and weird. Plus, a hundred bucks was more money than I'd ever seen a middle schooler carry around. Georgie must have noticed my confusion because he leaned in closer. Please, I've been saving up for months. Nobody else will do it. Something about the way he said it made me pause. This wasn't about showing off or some stupid dare. Georgie looks scared but determined. I pocketed the money and told him to meet me after school to explain what was really going on. We sat on the bleachers by the empty football field. Georgie kept glancing around like he was worried someone would see us talking. Up close, I could see bruises on his neck that looked a few days old. His homemade sling was because he couldn't afford a real doctor. Carson and his dad moved in with us two months ago. Georgie finally said his dad is dating

Have you ever been in a love triangle? I rejected my childhood friend for his brother, and now, 12 years later, I'm the one trying to win him back. I missed my best friend, Gavin, and I never got to tell him. Not after I heard him so badly he stopped talking to me and his own family. Why not just get him to forgive you? My mom asked, handing me Rex's wedding invitation. His brother, the guy I chose over Gavin 12 years back. F it, why not? It was there that I saw him the first time in years. Gavin, now taller, breathtaking and cold. I smiled and waved at him, but he looks right through me during the rehearsal dinner, like I was wallpaper. Just walk. Don't look at me, don't talk to me, Gavin said during the practice run. Should we at least try to pretend we're okay? He replied sharply. I've been pretending you don't exist for 12 years. One more day won't kill me. He sat far from me at dinner, left when I entered rooms, hopped over me when I tripped, and fell flat on my face. Even when Rex joked about baby brother, old crush, Gavin just yawned as if he was bored. Even thinking about me, it hurt, but all I could think was how he used to wait for me after school, carrying me on his back. When I got hurt at the wedding, my first goal was to get Near him, I switched our place cards, only to watch him switch seats. I wrote I'm sorry I called you a liar on a napkin and slipped it under his water glass. He looked at it, looked back at me, then used it to wipe up spilled champagne. Every plan failed spectacularly, but one thing did. Pick away at the ice around him. When a bridesmaid started crying, I sat on the floor with her, fixed her makeup, and made her laugh through the tears. I glanced up and Gavin was in the doorway, watching with a soft smile. I looked away, embarrassed, but when I looked back, he was gone. A lost opportunity that made me want to bang my head on the table. By eleven PM, I knew I blew it. I drank down a glass of champagne and sat in the back of the room, feeling sad and best friendless. I watched the groom, Rex, stand up to give his drunk and sloppy speech. Thank you all for coming here. And thanks also to my ex. He pointed at me. I sat up straight.

I screenshot everything and opened the editing app. My hands trembled circling her stomach just like she'd done to dozens of girls. I typed popular volleyball player hiding pregnancy. I want to send an email to the birthday girl's mom explaining why my daughter left the party early. My daughter was invited to a classmate's birthday party at a bowling alley. The event was an all girls party, and from what I could tell, there were about 17 girls in attendance. He arrived about five minutes late and walked in at the same time as another classmate, Betty. Due to a bit of a line, it took about 10 minutes for both girls to get their bowling shoes and head toward the reserved lanes. The hostess had booked three adjacent lanes. Like most bowling setups, each pair of lanes had a shared seating area with curved benches. When we got there, I noticed that lanes one and two already had several girls names programmed. On lane three, an adult male, someone I didn't recognize, was programming names into the system. When Annie approached the group, she was told to go to lane three. I greeted a few parents and noticed Annie walk away. I asked where she was going, and she said she'd been told to go find a blue bowling ball because it was lighter. I checked and realized the ball she was heading toward was actually 14 pounds. I went to find a lighter one and brought it back to her. A parent nearby asked if I was bowling. I said, no, just helping Annie get the right ball. At that moment, the dad of another girl, Called out to Betty that her name had been added to lane 2, and the birthday girl's mom, Dana, the hostess, came over. I asked her if Annie could be added to either lane one or two, assuming that all the girls would be mixed across the three lanes. Dana told me Annie was on lane three. I was surprised, so I walked over to look. Sure enough, Annie's name was on lane three. The only people bowling there were Annie and the adult male along with

How normal she looked. Mom tilted her head. Hospital? What are you talking about? I haven't been to a doctor in months. My last checkup was in March, and everything was fine. The flowers slipped out of my hand. But Kevin said you had heart problems and needed surgery. Heart problems? Mom laughed. Honey, I've been working in my garden all week. Yesterday I moved three bags of mulch by myself. Where did Kevin get that idea? That's when it hit me. Kevin had played me. He'd used Mom's health to scam me out of $2,000. And he knew exactly which buttons to push. He knew I'd feel guilty about not calling mom enough. I called Kevin immediately, hands shaking from anger. Hey, man, how's mom doing? I asked, giving him a chance to come clean. Oh, much better. The doctor said she can rest at home now. Thanks again for helping out. Funny thing, Kevin. I'm standing in mom's kitchen right now, and she says she's never been to any hospital. Dead silence. Look, I can explain, he started. Mom, come here for a second, I said. I put the phone on speaker. Kevin wants to tell you about your hospital visit. What hospital visit? Mom asked loudly. Kevin, what is going on? Kevin tried to spin some story about how mom must have forgotten because of stress. But mom wasn't having it. She tore into him right there on speaker phone, asking how he could lie about her Health. To steal money from his own brother? That's when Kevin finally broke down and admitted it. He spent the money on a weekend trip to Vegas with his girlfriend, Ashley. He'd blown it all on poker and expensive dinners. You used my fake death to fund your vacation? Mom was furious. Are you insane? When

When has someone tried to guilt trip you? My brother Kevin had been asking me for money since we were teenagers, and I'd always said yes. The guy borrowed, like, $50 here, $100 there, and somehow never remembered to pay me back. But this was different. I was eating cereal and watching Netflix on a Tuesday night when my phone rang. Kevin was crying actual tears, which freaked me out because he never cried about anything. Dude, you gotta help me, he said between sobs. Mom's in the hospital, and they're saying if we don't pay these bills right now, they're gonna stop her treatment. My stomach dropped. I hadn't talked to mom in, like, two weeks because work had been crazy. The guilt hit me like a truck. What happened? Is she okay? I asked, already reaching for my laptop to check my bank account. Heart problems, Kevin said. The doctor say it's serious and they need $2,000 today or they're transferring her to some crappy public hospital. I already spent everything I had on the ambulance ride. I felt like the worst son ever. While I was sitting there watching stupid shows, mom was suffering and I didn't even know. Kevin kept talking about how scared he was and how mom didn't want to worry me because she knew I was stressed with my new job. Send me your Venmo, I said. I didn't even think twice. I transferred $2,000 that was supposed to be for my car. Payment. Kevin was so grateful, thanking me over and over. He promised he'd pay me back as soon as insurance kicked in. I felt better knowing I'd helped, but the guilt was still eating at me. Three days later, I drove to Mom's house with flowers and soup. I figured she'd be resting at home by now. When I knocked, mom answered the door, looking perfectly fine, like she was wearing her garden

What's the most genius way you've dealt with a controlling partner and actually got them to stop? I admit it. I messed up. I had forgotten my phone was on silent, and so for two hours straight, I sweated my butt off on Smash Bros. At my friend's house and forgot to text my girlfriend Cindy back. So when I finally saw her, 15 missed calls, she was furious. I need to know you're actually where you say you are, she said. But I already sent you my location and a picture of us on the coach. It's not enough. What if there are girls hiding behind you on the couch? Or what if it's just an old picture? I'm not stupid. From now on, when you're out, we video call so I can see. Or you can wake up single the next day. She hung up, practically foaming at the mouth. The first few calls were painfully awkward. I'd have to go around the house, introduce each of my friends to her, basically give her a house tour to show it's all clear before she hang up. And randomly call again in the next hour or so to make sure I didn't change locations or invited over girls to my friend's house. After a few days like this, everyone was going crazy over her rule. My friend Jeff pulled me to the side with a concerned look. Dude, honestly, if she's gonna act crazy, you gotta do it, too. That's when it came to me. A brilliant idea. The next time I was at Jeff's house, I answered Cindy's call in my best David Attenborough voice. Here we observe the male human in his natural habitat. Approaching the buffalo wings with caution, I slowly turned the camera towards my friends, who immediately caught on and started acting like wildlife. In the background, dinner was pretending to be a gazelle and Jeff was chest beating like a gorilla. Very funny, Cindy said, rolling her eyes at us. The next Friday, we took it further. I answered the call holding a microphone, reading out a fake weather forecast, while Jeff held up a map glued to a pizza box. Currently, we're experiencing a high pressure system of Mario Kart moving through the living room area, I announced. Temperatures are rising as we travel through Rainbow Road. Now back to you, Cindy. Stop being weird.

I disowned my adoptive son since he chose his people over us. We adopted Jalen when he was 8. His birth mom was my younger sister who overdosed when he was 6, and his dad was nowhere to be found. I was 32 at the time with no kids of my own, and my husband Mike was completely on board. We figured we'd give Jalen the stable home he deserved after bouncing between foster homes for two years. Ellen was this quiet, serious kid who'd seen way too much for his age. He'd flinch whenever we raised our voices, even if we were just calling him for dinner from the other room. It took months before he'd laugh at my terrible dad jokes or let us hug him without going stiff. But slowly, he started opening up. He'd help Mike in the garage on weekends, asked me to pack extra snacks for school, started calling us mom and dad around his 10th birthday. For years, everything was perfect. Helen made good grades, played baseball in middle school, had friends over for sleepovers. We never hid his adoption from him, but he seemed completely settled with us. When he turned 16, I taught him to drive in our old Honda Civic. Mike took him fishing every summer. We were a real family. But then his senior year, something changed. Jalen started asking more questions about his birth family. Where they lived, if he had any siblings, what happened to his dad, I tried to be honest but gentle, telling him what little I knew. His birth mom had struggled with addiction, bounced around a lot, made poor choices. His dad had left when Jalen was 3 and never came back. One day in February, Jalen came home from school acting weird. He kept checking his phone during dinner and barely touched his food. When I asked what was wrong, he said some guy named Carlos had messaged him on Instagram, claiming to be his older half brother. My stomach dropped. I knew Carlos existed, but had hoped he'd never surface. Carlos was 19, lived about three hours away, and according to Jalen

I accidentally joined a neighborhood cult because I wanted free pizza. Look, in my defense, I heard the words free pizza and my brain immediately shut off every survival instinct. I had no thoughts, no hesitation, just a hungry idiot following the scent of melted cheese like a cartoon character floating toward a high on a window sill. It started with a block party flyer stuck to my door. Come meet your neighbors! Free pizza, breadsticks, and drinks! I just moved in, didn't know anyone, and I figured, hey, this is how normal people make friends. So Saturday rolls around and I show up at the Big House at the end of the hold the sack expecting, like, a chill barbecue vibe. You know, paper plates, kids running around, someone's dog begging for scraps. Instead, I walk in and immediately notice two things. Everyone is dressed in matching maroon robes. There's a massive golden breadstick mounted on the wall like the freaking holy Grail. Now, a normal, functioning adult would see this and leave. But not me. Nope. I see a tower of pizza boxes on the kitchen island and think maybe it's just one of those quirky HOA things. So I grab a slice, sit down, and start eating. That's when papa Tony shows up. Big guy, beard that looks like he glued bread crumbs to his face, robe with fancier embroidery than the others. That's a hand on my shoulder and goes, welcome, Brother Crust. Tonight you join Us in honoring the Holy Dough. At this point, you'd think I'd panic, but all I could think was, Brother Crust, that's kind of badass. Before I know it, they're handing me a robe. I try to say no, but someone's already tying it around my neck like a super hero Cape. Papatoni leads us all into the living room, which, by the way, had been cleared of furniture except for an altar covered in marinara candles, and starts chanting, in yeast we trust, in carbs we are bound. The whole group is chanting along, swaying side to side, and I'm just there holding a breadstick like a

What did your family pretend was normal but really wasn't? We had a basement dog named biscuit. That's what mom called him. Never allowed upstairs, never went outside, never saw the vet. Just lived in our basement in Denver for 8 years. Some dogs are indoor dogs, she'd say when I asked why biscuit couldn't come to the park. He's shy. The rules about biscuit were non negotiable. Only mom feeds him. Never go downstairs after 9 p m. Don't tell friends about our special dog. If he makes noise during dinner parties, turn the TV louder. I was 12 when I started questioning things. What kind of dog barks in perfect English words sometimes? Why did his howls sound like help, please? Must be my imagination. Dad said dogs make weird sounds. My little sister Amy loved biscuit. Would sneak him cookies through the basement door slot. One day, she dropped her doll down there. There. And cried until mom let her retrieve it. She came back confused. Biscuit has hands, she whispered to me. He gave me my doll with hands, mom heard. Amy spent the weekend at Grandma's for lying. When she came back, she never mentioned Biscuit's hands again. I started paying attention. Biscuits food bowls were always plastic plates and cups, never dog bowls. His kibble looked suspiciously like cereal. His water bowl had a straw in it. Sometimes the basement door had seven locks, seven from the outside. One night, I heard biscuit howling. Again. But this time, I pressed my ear to the floor. It wasn't howling. It was crying. Sobbing. Human sobbing. I snuck Dad's keys while he slept. Crept to the basement door at three a

What's the one sentence your kids said that instantly silenced a whole room? I was at one of those chaotic indoor play places for my son Leo's seventh birthday party. He'd spent the entire hour at the ticket spewing Jackpot game, his face a mask of pure concentration. Finally, he hit the grand prize. A river of 1,000 tickets poured out of the machine. He was ecstatic, clutching the massive paper snake to his chest like a holy relic. That's when I saw him. A little boy, maybe five years old, pointed at Leo's tickets. I want that one. His father, a guy in an expensive tracksuit who'd been on his phone the whole time, came over. He didn't look at me, only at the tickets. Hey, my son wants those, let him have them. I was genuinely stunned. I'm sorry, what? My son just won these. The dad let out a long breath like I was a massive inconvenience. Look, he's having a meltdown. Just give him the tickets. The kids birthday party. They need to learn to share, right? I stared at him. No, he saved his tokens. All party to win this. He's not giving it away. He raised his voice loud enough for the other parents at our party table to hear. Are you serious? You're going to let your kid be selfish over a bunch of worthless paper? What kind of values are you teaching him? I could feel the blood in my cheeks. Kind Of values where you don't hand over your things just because someone throws a tantrum. Now he was practically yelling, my son is having a bad day. You're raising a spoiled brat who doesn't care about other people's feelings. His son was still screaming. And now other families were starting to stare at the scene he was creating. Leo had been watching the whole thing. He looked from the screaming boy to the angry father, then down at his precious roll of tickets. The father saw his chance and knelt down, his voice sickly sweet. Hey, little man.

They said I was too small for football, so I made them regret every word. On championship night, I was 5 feet 6 inches and 145 pounds as a high school freshman. The size of a decent seventh grader. My dad's jeans had cursed me with a body better suited for cross country than contact sports. But I didn't wanna run in circles. I wanted to play football. Coach Morris looked at me like I was roadkill when I showed up for tryouts. 30 seconds into my first drills, I heard it. Wilson, what are you doing here? The chess club meets in the library. The team erupted in laughter. Kept my mouth shut. Finish the drill. You're gonna get yourself killed out here, kid. Coach said afterward, why don't you try something else? Maybe track? I looked him straight in the eye. I wanna play. He sighed. Fine. You can be equipment manager, help with practice. Maybe in a few years, if you grow. So that's what I did. I washed jerseys, fixed helmets, set up cones and filled water bottles while the actual players got to play. After everyone left, I'd run the same drills they did. I set up tackling dummies and hit them until my shoulders ache. I studied playbooks like they were sacred tech. Junior year, I grown two inches and added 20 pounds of muscle. Still small, but solid. I tried out again. This time I didn't just run drills. I demolished them. My 40 yard dash was second fastest on the team. My route running was precise. My hands never dropped a pass. Not bad, coach admitted. But this isn't a practice drill. This is varsity football. Those guys across town would snap you like a twig. He put me on special teams. The Suicide Squad. Just bodies to throw at kick returns. First game of the season, I flew down the field on kickoff, weaving through blockers twice my size, and made a tackle that echoed through the stadium. The crowd erupted. Coach ignored it, called it lucky. Then I did it again the next game. And the next. By mid season, I forced two fumbles on kick returns. Fans started chanting will, son! Will, son! Whenever kickoff came. Except for Brandon Reeves, our star quarterback and the coach's godson. 6 foot 3, college scouts at every game. Arrogance as big as his arm. He made it his mission to.

My mother demanded I hand over my house to her because my little sister needs it more than me. I bought my first house last year after saving for six years. It's not fancy, but it's mine. My sister Emma is 25, dropped out of college twice, and still lives in mom's basement. Last month she announced she's pregnant with some guy named Dave, already has three kids with two different women, and works part time at a gas station. Yesterday, mom calls saying they want to stop by and see how I've decorated the place. She's never cared about my decorating before, but now she insisted on bringing Emma along. They show up at 6 p m. With measuring tape, notebooks, and Emma's carrying a folder full of paint samples. I thought maybe Emma wanted decorating tips for her own future place. Boy, was I wrong. Emma immediately starts walking through every room like she's conducting a home inspection. She's measuring doorways and windows with her phone app, taking photos of electrical outlets, and making notes about where the crib would go. And this would be perfect for a nursery. She even opens my closets and starts talking about storage space for baby clothes. Mom sitting on my couch like she's conducting a business meeting, nodding approvingly at everything Emma says. Every few minutes, she'd call out suggestions like, don't forget to measure for the changing table and check if that window gets good morning light. After 30 minutes, Of this increasingly weird behavior. I finally asked what was going on. Mom puts down her notebook and drops the nuke. We've been doing a lot of thinking about Emma's situation lately. She needs a stable environment for the baby. And honestly, you're single with all this extra space. It just makes perfect sense when you really think about it. I'm standing there confused. When she continues without missing a beat. Emma's going to move in next month with Dave, and they'll start.

My family used me as free daycare, so I made their vacation a permanent one. My family discovered I was good with kids when I was 14 and babysat my cousin once. That single afternoon turned me into their unpaid nanny for the next 12 years. My sister would drop off her toddler for just an hour while she ran to target. One hour became three, then six, until she'd stroll back with fresh acrylic nails, a Starbucks Frappuccino, and zero apologies. I remember sitting on my bedroom floor surrounded by broken crayons and goldfish crackers, realizing I'd missed my entire shift at the local coffee shop because of her lies. Then my brother discovered the family gold mine. Midnight texts became routine. Emergency babysitting needed. The twins, regular sitter canceled. Of course, the emergency was always tickets to concerts, bar crawls, or weekend getaways with his girlfriend. I Learned to sleep with my phone on silent. College should have been my escape, but my family had other plans. My sister would show up unannounced at my dorm, sometimes driving four hours just to dump her kids on me for entire weekends. He cost me my first serious girlfriend when she called during our anniversary dinner screaming about a fake emergency. I watched her look at me across that candlelit table and say she couldn't compete with my family's chaos anymore. After graduation, things got worse. My parents, claiming they wanted to help me settle in, secretly made copies of My apartment keys and distributed them to my siblings like VIP passes. I dragged myself home from my marketing job exhausted from client presentations, only to find my living room transformed into a daycare center, toys scattered everywhere, juice boxes leaking on my white couch, and kids I hadn't even agreed to watch. My boss pulled me aside after I missed my third important presentation.

What is the creepiest glitch in the matrix you've experienced? One. I had an Android phone which had a Google Cards feature option that could notify you like 15 minutes to home if you were out. I thought this feature was annoying and useless, so I kept the feature off. After several months of no card notifications, one night I'm at home and a card pops up saying 35 minutes to home, pinning me at a random intersection on the other side of town. Let's call it First Street in Story Avenue, I think. That's weird. I'm not even way over there. I don't even know where that is. I've never been to that area. I go to my card setting to turn it back off, but it's already turned off. That's weird. The next night the same thing happens. 35 minutes to home from 1st Saint Story. What the. Still definitely not over there. Check cards feature and the notifications are still turned off, so no idea why I'm getting a notification. A few days later, a friend and I are out running errands and he misses his intended exit, so he takes the next one. Once on the streets, I ask where are we? I've never been over here. a car to our right tries to turn left and crashes right into us. Messed up the wheel turning system, so we pulled forward to the curb to call a tow truck. We had our kids in the Car. So I called my sister to pick us all up. When my sister asks me for the location, I look up at the street signs. First Street and Story Avenue. 2 in college, I delivered pizzas to make money. I had a delivery that should have taken about 20 minutes. When I returned to the store, the manager asked me what had taken so long. I asked him what he meant, and he pointed to the computer, showing I had been gone for an hour and seven minutes. I don't remember delivering the pizza, only turning into the store when I was returning. 20 years later, I still have no idea what happened. Three. I had a dream of some kid that I had never seen before, dancing at a busy party. He was wearing a blue shirt, black pants, had Bieber hair, and there was a purple strobe light on the wall behind him. Wake up, think to myself, huh, what an odd dream, and carry on with my life. Several years later, I was at my cousin's wedding reception, chilling and hanging out with a different cousin. Music comes on and we start jumping up and down. And then I realized that I was reliving the dream. Same clothes, same hair, same purple lighting in the background. 4 A few months before my first car accident, I dreamed about it happening. Everything from the sounds to the placement and the smell was the same. The thing is, The girl driving tried to get me to find a different ride because she didn't want to do any extra driving that day. And after the crash I told her about my dream and she said she had the same one the night before and that's why she didn't want to drive. Freaky. 5 I once was woke up by a phone call from my GF. At the time she was at her friend's house, which I didn't know about until the phone call. We figured out our plans for the day. Told her that I was gonna lay around for 15 minutes to wake up a bit. I'd have a shower and head over to get her. I just laid down, started to fall asleep. Then the phone rang about 15 minutes after the last phone call. It was her calling from her friend's house again. Convo was the same word for word, so I played along. Then when it was done, she was wondering why I was laughing. I told her we just had this convo 15 minutes ago. She disagreed and I figured was pulling my leg. Later that day I checked my calls, only had one from that number. And she showed me her friend's phone. Same, only one call made. 6 I knew someone that fell asleep drunk on a three story flat roof which they rolled off of during the night. The doctors said the main reason he didn't break anything was that his Body was in such a state of relaxation from the booze induced coma he was in that he pretty much just bounced off the concrete.

When did you triumphantly call someone out for lying? One, at my job recently, a woman claimed I had promised her something for free when in fact all I did was offer her a significant discount. She came in demanding it for free and I refused. She said she had a recording of me saying it was free. I don't know what her endgame was, but on the off chance I had messed up what I said badly enough, I would honor it, I asked her to play me the recording. She refused because I was being difficult. She actually had the nerve to ask for my boss's number so she could complain about me not honoring a product for free valued at around $400 and thought they would actually side with her. 2. I created a binder for a hotel my company owns with forms and templates. I highlighted and wrote explanations on everything. About a month later, I go to the property to assist with some things and the GM brings out the binder and says, yeah, I just put this together as a tool for us here. I immediately tell him, no, you didn't. I made that and gave it to you. His face went white as he tried to recover saying, well, I added a few things. He didn't love the faces of my colleagues when I went back to the office and told them all three. When I worked at a fast food place, I Had someone call in during the opening shift while we were still prepping everything for the day. He tells me he was just there and that the service was terrible and his order was wrong. I asked him when exactly he came in. He said about half an hour ago. I said, oh, that's weird because we don't even open for another 45 minutes. He just hung up without a word. 4, my ex wife told my kids I didn't pay child support regularly. I was able to lay out each and every receipt for three years showing each payment made on time or early. But I wouldn't say triumphant. There are no winners in divorce. 5, my friend's favorite is from when working at Mickey D's. She was on drive drive through and a guy came through complaining about the ice cream he got earlier. That's when everyone who worked there came to the drive through window to see. Friend casually lets them know they haven't had a working ice cream machine in four months. Six, at an auto shop, angry customer ahead of me was shouting, we've been here more than two hours. The shop manager gets out a piece of paper. We printed the work order you signed less than 30 minutes ago. Seven, I was waiting at a red light behind a red BMW. I saw that its bumper was kind of messed up. The light turns green and he starts going and I slowly accelerate. Like any normal human. Then he slams on his brakes and I do the same. Don't hit him at all. He reverses into my car and turns on his hazards and pulls into the shopping complex near us. We exchange information. I am absolutely calm. Later at small claims court after rejecting his claim with my insurance, he goes, yes, your honour, this rear ending left me with 5,000 in damage including paint and 1 thousand in emotional distress as I have needed physical therapy. Judge looks at me and you say you have video of this incident. Me. Yes, I do, sir. And I hand the CD to the bailiff. The dash cam clearly shows his fraud. Judge, so is that you in the video? Him. Um, he literally got arrested and had to pay me 5,000 in damages. Get a dash cam, people. 8. I had a customer once call and say she had bought these ice cream sandwiches the week before and they were all freezer burned. She was super aggressive and was yelling. So I very politely confirmed the exact product she bought. She yelled, yes, that one. That's what I've been telling you. And I said, miss, we discontinued those six months ago. She stuttered a bit and hung up. I was 19. It was my first job and it was so satisfying.

What's the scariest thing you've woken up to? One, when he was little, my younger son wouldn't try and wake you up if he needed something. He'd do that creepy thing kids do where they just stand there looking at you until you wake up. Well, I wake up at about 1:00am in a dark bedroom and see the black silhouette of a young kid standing right next to the bed. Golly, that's scary. Then he asked, hey, dad, Wanna play Rock Band 2? Waking up to my husband yelling, get out of my house. A man broke into my house and crawled in bed with me. Turns out he was in the house for a couple of hours. According to my door camera, my husband was asleep on the couch, came to bed and found the guy on the bed beside me asleep. Also, I accidentally left my door unlocked when I lived in this studio apartment in Philly. I woke up and it felt like someone was watching me. You know that feeling. Then I heard a shuffling noise and turn the lights on. There was a guy in a hoodie standing at the foot of my bed. I screamed. It was a young drunk dude that I literally had to push out. He seemed confused, but I'll never know what his intent was. I've never left my door unlocked since 3. Once I woke up to go to the bathroom, got up, smack something, slap me in The face. Turns out it was my entire right arm. Completely numb. Nearly scared the piss out of me and concerned me greatly afterwards. Has not happened since. 4. Back when I lived alone in an apartment, I used to wake up to just about anything. Never woke up more terrified than the night when I woke up to the sound of my toilet flushing. To this day, I can only assume that a ghost just couldn't hold it anymore. Five, I woke up and my dad's alarm clock was going off through the wall. He was a really light sleeper and he always turned it off immediately. It had been going off for several minutes and I think I knew before I got to his room that he was no longer with me. It was just so incredibly out of character for that alarm to be going off like that. He went in his sleep with a blanket still completely undisturbed. And I think I felt some small comfort at that, even though I was just a kid. 6, I once woke up to an earthquake at 4:00am. I lived in a house over the ocean on stilts, so my house was rocking like crazy. It was my first earthquake. And for some reason my brain first thought that someone was robbing me. I grabbed a machete and ran outside shirtless in my underwear. Neighbors next to me looked at me alarmed and started laughing. 7, my partner waking. Me up during a camping trip. He woke me to gather all our gear and our dogs into our truck ASAP. Lightning we had spotted six hours earlier in the day had sparked a wildfire. We got out as ash and sparks were falling around us. When we reached the top of the ridge surrounding our camp, we got out to look and watch the fire eat our entire campsite. We're so glad we called in the strike when we saw it. We met fire crews on our way out. The fire burned for like a week. One of the fires in Oregon in 2020, the Lakeview Paisley Fire 8, a bed bug infestation. I had had them for weeks and had no idea what they were. I would see one or two here or there and I'd just squash them, wonder what they were and move on. One morning, I woke up early and found quite a few of them on my bed. I started looking more closely and realised that the creases of the mattress were infested with them. Then I started to do some research, Learned that I had bed bugs, felt my soul leave my body, then began the process of getting rid of them. They're a psychological horror experience I wouldn't wish upon my worst enemy. Five years after the fact, and I still get paranoia attacks at a random speck in the sheets or mysterious red marks in the morning.

People who got expelled from school. What did you do in 9th grade? I got the teacher everybody wanted for biology. Except one morning our entire class could hear her outside the room getting chewed out by our assistant principal for being late on grading. We also knew she had lost her sister the week before, so she was having a really rough time. A few minutes into teaching, she started explaining something about our final exam and the guys next to me were passing notes. They usually did it every time she turned around, but this time she saw them. She usually wouldn't have cared, but she thought it was something about her. So she walked over and asked to see it. Kid shook his head without saying anything. So she basically reached into his pocket to grab the note. She started reading it in front of the class and said, I left it in the garbage bin in room W12. It's all there with the. And stopped herself before reading the rest out loud. She looked down at the boy, clearly having read something bad and didn't know what to say. Her face was pale and not knowing what to do. She grabbed them both and literally yanked them out of the room. We all sat there confused for a half hour wondering what that note said. There were police at our school and they asked our whole route to come to the office. They questioned everybody about It, but nobody knew anything. And by the time they let us go, they had sent everybody home. We later found out that the note said there was a key to the office in that garbage bin along with a loaded gun. Both of them denied writing it and said they didn't know who it was for. So they decided to fire our teacher for creating a school wide panic and expelled our entire row.

My teacher thought I was cheating on a test, so she sent me to the ER. When I was in ninth grade, I got stuck with our school's worst teacher, who was infamous for trying to make a Muslim girl take off her headwear to prove she wasn't wearing headphones in class. There were a lot of students who got away with cheating by wearing headphones during tests, so she was constantly checking. Since then, she didn't do anything too bad until we had to take our final exam at the end of the year, and she stood up to walk around the room. It was really hot that day, so I wore a lighter shirt. I also happened to have type 1 diabetes, so you could see my insulin pump. That day, my blood sugar was low, so I turned my pump on and walked into class. We were almost done taking the test, and she stood up to walk around the room. I was honestly focused on just passing until I heard her walk straight up behind me. In that moment, two things happened. She grabbed my paper off my desk and told me I failed, and I felt her grab the pump on my waist. I just sat there in shock as she walked away and had no idea what had just happened. However, it wasn't until I noticed she was holding Scissors that it clicked what she had just done. She seen the wire hanging off My waist and assumed I had headphones in. When I looked down, the tube was cut. After a few seconds, my pump started beeping very loudly and everyone started looking at me. A few people sitting around me saw what happened and were in shock. She came over and when she realized what she did, I watched her face turn pale. She had messed up big time and had no idea what to do, and neither did I. She told me to go to the nurse, and on the way there, I started getting. I made it there. Could feel myself starting to pass out. The nurse called 9 1 1 and I had to go to the hospital. But since that day, I actually started wearing headphones in class because none of the teachers would try anything.

How do I tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real? It started at Thanksgiving when my cousin wouldn't shut up about me being single. She kept asking why I never brought anyone home, making these fake concerned faces at the dinner table. So when she said, I must be dating someone special, I just nodded, gave him a name right on the spot. Daniel said he was busy with work. My family ate it up. But then Christmas rolled around and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her coworker, Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. She showed me his Instagram, tall brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem, he didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed. After that first dinner, my mom kept inviting him back, Easter brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. He started sending my brother updates about basketball. Scores. My dad asked him to help fix our back porch. The worst part was how natural it felt. We drive to my parents house together and he'd ask about my day like we actually dated. He remembered my coffee order, knew I hated mushrooms, grab my jacket when I got cold. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. One night after my aunt's birthday party, we sat in his car outside my apartment in complete silence. Everyone had spent the whole night saying how perfect we looked together, how lucky I was. My grandmother even pulled me aside to say Daniel was a keeper. The whole car ride home, I kept stealing glances at him, wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us. She found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly, made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me, we can't keep this up forever. You know, that message hit me like a truck. I realized he was ready to end this whole thing and I wasn't, not even close. Instead of texting back, Or giving him some weird speech. I invited him over for dinner at my place, cooked his favorite pasta dish, the one my mom always made when he came over, set the table with actual candles, not just the overhead light. After we finished eating, I was washing dishes and he was drying them, just like we did at my parents house. That's when I finally said it. I know this whole thing started as pretend, but it doesn't feel fake.

How do I tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real? It started at Thanksgiving when my cousin wouldn't shut up about me being single. She kept asking why I never brought anyone home, making these fake concerned faces at the dinner table. So when she said, I must be dating someone special, I just nodded, gave him a name right on the spot. Daniel said he was busy with work. My family ate it up. But then Christmas rolled around and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her coworker, Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. She showed me his Instagram, tall brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem, he didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed. After that first dinner, my mom kept inviting him back, Easter brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. He started sending my brother updates about basketball. Scores. My dad asked him to help fix our back porch. The worst part was how natural it felt. We drive to my parents house together and he'd ask about my day like we actually dated. He remembered my coffee order, knew I hated mushrooms, grab my jacket when I got cold. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. One night after my aunt's birthday party, we sat in his car outside my apartment in complete silence. Everyone had spent the whole night saying how perfect we looked together, how lucky I was. My grandmother even pulled me aside to say Daniel was a keeper. The whole car ride home, I kept stealing glances at him, wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us. She found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly, made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me, we can't keep this up forever. You know, that message hit me like a truck. I realized he was ready to end this whole thing and I wasn't, not even close. Instead of texting back, Or giving him some weird speech. I invited him over for dinner at my place, cooked his favorite pasta dish, the one my mom always made when he came over, set the table with actual candles, not just the overhead light. After we finished eating, I was washing dishes and he was drying them, just like we did at my parents house. That's when I finally said it. I know this whole thing started as pretend, but it doesn't feel fake.

By year six, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward. After three Years of zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living room. Through the window, we watched my ex climbing out of a U Haul truck pulling suitcases toward our front door. She still had our old house key. She walked straight into our kitchen like she own

I told my mom that I'm disgusted by and ashamed of my sister. It started when my sister Chloe came home crying because her boyfriend Jake dumped her. She's 25 and I'm 17, but she always acts like she's the victim in every situation. This time was different, though. She kept saying Jake was horrible and cruel. But when I asked what happened, she got all shifty. He said he broke up with her out of nowhere and kicked her out of his apartment. But then she mentioned she still had keys to his place because she forgot to give them back the next day. She left early in the morning and came back with this huge golden retriever. I recognized him immediately. It was Buster, Jake's dog. Jake love that dog more than anything. When his grandpa died last year, Buster was the only thing that helped him through it. I asked Chloe why she had Buster and she got this weird smile on her face. She said Jake didn't deserve to keep him since he broke her heart. Then she said something that made my stomach drop. She told me she was going to take Buster to the vet tomorrow to put him down as payback for what Jake did to her. I couldn't believe what I was hearing. This dog was completely healthy and happy, just confused about being in a new place. Buster kept looking around for Jake and whining by the door. It was heartbreaking. I told Chloe she was being insane and she couldn't just kill someone's dog because she was upset. She laughed and said Jake should have thought about that before he decided to hurt her. Then she said if I told anyone, she'd make sure I regretted it. That night I couldn't sleep. I kept thinking about Buster and how scared he must be. Around 2:00am, I heard Chloe on the phone with someone probably making the vet appointment. I knew I had to do something. Then next morning, Chloe left for work and told mom she was taking Buster for a walk later. Mom didn't know the whole story. Chloe just said Jake asked her to watch his dog for a few days. As soon as both then were gone, I called Jake. He picked up on the first ring and sounded terrible. I told him Chloe had Buster and was planning to put him down today. He went completely silent for like 10 seconds, then started freaking out. He said he'd been looking everywhere for Buster and thought maybe he got out somehow. I told Jake to come over now while Chloe was at work. He was at our house in 15 minutes. When he saw Buster, he literally started crying. Buster went crazy with excitement, jumping all over him and licking his face. I opened the door and Jake carried his dog out to his car. Before he left, Jake told me what really happened with Chloe. She Didn't just get dumped. She cheated on him with his best friend, Marcus. When Jake found out, he broke up with her and told her to move out. She stole Buster on her way out and left Jake's spare key on the counter so he thought she was being mature about the breakup. A few hours later, Chloe came home and went straight to look for Buster when she couldn't find him. She started screaming my name. She found me in my room and absolutely lost it. She called me a traitor and said I had no right to interfere in her business. Then mom came home and asked what all the yelling was about. Chloe told her I let some guy steal her dog. She made it sound like I just gave away her pet to a random stranger. Mom looked.

What's the hilarious thing your grandma has ever done? My 82 year old grandma Dorothy discovered Amazon Prime last month. This woman who still doesn't trust ATMs and hides cash in cookie tins somehow figured out one click ordering. It started innocently. My cousin set up her account so she could order sunflower seeds for the cardinals in her yard. First delivery, 40 pounds of bird seed. Perfect. Second delivery, 80 pounds of bird seed just in case. Third delivery, an inflatable hot tub. Grandma, why did you buy a hot tub? I didn't buy hot tub. I just pushed button. But since it's here, she set it up in her small backyard. Soon her neighbors, Mrs. Johnson, Mrs. Miller and Mrs. Green, all in their 70s, started coming over for joint therapy sessions. They sit in the hot tub fully clothed because as grandma says, bikinis are for teenagers. Fourth delivery, a karaoke machine for hot tub nights. Now every Thursday evening, four elderly women sit in a hot tub belting out Elvis and Dolly Parton songs at top volume. Fifth delivery, 120 cans of Vienna sausages. It was bargain such deal. Grandma, you don't even like Vienna sausages but raccoons do. She's now feeding every raccoon in the county. Premium sausages. 6 delivery, a drone. Why do you need a drone? To spy on squirrels from kitchen she flew at once. It's now stuck in Mr Johnson's oak tree. He's convinced it's government surveillance and sprays it with The garden hose every morning. Seventh delivery. A 70 inch TV. Old TV. Too small. Grandma, your old TV was 60 inches. Yes, too small. Hard to see Judge Judy. She watches Judge Judy at volume 90 and yells advice at the screen like she's a co judge. The breaking point was delivery number eight. Motorcycle helmet. Grandma, you don't have a motorcycle? Not yet. Not yet. That's when I checked her Amazon cart. She had a Harley Davidson saved for later. I changed her password immediately. Why ruin my fun? Because you almost bought a motorcycle. It had good reviews. Now she has to call me Lana to order anything. But she found a loophole. She Learned Instacart. Last week, 50 watermelons showed up at her door. They sell by watermelon, not by pound. Deal of lifetime. She handed out watermelons to neighbors, delivery guys, even the UPS driver. Our street looks like a farmers market. Yesterday she called Lana. What's cryptocurrency? Why? Man on Facebook says I can turn watermelons into Bitcoin. Grandma, no, but he wears suit and picture looks smart. I rushed over. She was about to invest in something called Agricoin. Grandma, it's a scam, he said. I'm genius investor called me Warren Buffett of Ohio. She pouted then perked up. Lana, while you're here, help me set up TikTok. Mrs. Miller says. I could be influencer. Her username is now at hot tub grandma. 82. She has 20,000 followers in three weeks. Her top Video feeding Vienna sausages to raccoons while singing Dolly Parton. Comments are all. Protect this woman at all costs. She reads every comment through giant reading glasses and replies, bless your heart.

You ever been happy about intentionally manipulating someone? Every Thursday for three years, I told my wife Becca the same thing. I'm going to hang with the boys tonight, be back around midnight. Truth is, I was driving to the cinema to watch movies alone because I just needed some me time. But then two months ago, my movie ended abruptly and I came home two hours earlier than planned. When I turned onto our street, there was a black infinity in our driveway. My heart stopped as I watched back all the footage from our doorbell camera and saw a man getting out of the car and walk hang up like he done it before. Becca opened, before he could ring, they kissed the kind where her hand went to his neck. My stomach dropped. I wanted to burst through that door and confront them, but I decided on the spot that that would be too kind. I need did to do something else, something that would destroy her. So I drove around until 12:30 and walked in with a story about Tony getting drunk. Becca was showering. Hey, babe, how was your night? Good. You know how it is. Then next two Thursdays, I kept my routine but park down the street at 8:30 to watch. At the same time, the same car pulled up. I zoomed in on the ring footage and that's when it hit me. The man was Mark. Mark who supposedly moved to Seattle. Two years ago, my knees were shaking, but I took screenshots and sent them to my lawyer to further build my case. When I was confident enough that I had everything basically set up, I dropped a bomb. Becca was going on about her fake plans for when I left for boys night when I randomly blurted out, you know who I miss? Mark. That guy and I used to have so much fun before he moved to Seattle. Her fork stopped halfway to her mouth just for a second. Yeah, Mark was great. You guys still text though, right? Sometimes. The next morning she woke up different with this nervous energy. She made some phone calls behind closed doors. And since it was Thursday during lunch, she texted, what time are you heading out tonight? She never asked before, so I knew the comment about Mark got her probably 7:30. Why? Just wondering. The guys doing anything special? Same old after work. She was cooking in full makeup. You look nice, I said. Just felt like making an effort for you to come home to. But she kept checking her phone and setting it down, then pick getting it back up at 7:15. She practically pushed me out. Don't want you to be late. Tell everyone I say hi. I drove to my regular spot down the street where I watched them, but this time there was no car that showed up. And at 9:15, Becca's own car pulled Out I followed her. First stop, O'malley Sports Bar, where she thought I'd be. She walked in confidently, then came out five minutes later looking confused, checking her phone, scanning the parking lot. Then she got back in her car. Her second stop, the dugout, another sports bar. Through the windows, I watched her walk the entire place, moving table to table, even checking the bathroom entrance area. She showed her phone to a waitress who shrugged. Back to the car, more frantic phone checking. Third stop, Buffalo Wild Wings. She stayed longer, this time, 15 minutes. I could see her at the bar talking to the manager, showing him something on her phone, probably my pic. He shook his head, pointed to their mostly empty tables. Thursday wasn't exactly prime sports bar night. Fourth stop, the dive bar where Tony actually used to drag us. She went straight to the bartender. I slipped in through the side door, ducked into the hallway by the bathrooms, heard her say every Thursday night, group of guys, probably five or six of them loud. One of them looks like this. The bartender studied her phone. Thursday's our slowest night. I definitely remember a regular group. Sorry. She left looking frustrated, sat in her car for five minutes typing furiously. Then she drove to the a m. C theater. I gave her a 10 minute head start, then walked in through the side entrance. She was at the concession stand talking to the Teenage manager showed her phone again. He pointed toward the theaters. She went to check each one. Open doors, scanning the sparse Thursday night crowds. I went back to my car. 20 minutes later, she emerged looking defeated, sat in her car for another 10 minutes. Through her rear window, I could see her on the phone gesturing with her free hand, probably calling Mark, probably saying she couldn't find me anywhere. That maybe I knew that Thursday nights might not be safe anymore. She even drove by two more bars on the way home. Quick stops, desperate checks. When I got home at my U full time, she was on the couch with wine, trying to look casual, but her leg was bouncing. How was your night? Studying my face. Good. Same as always. Yeah. Where exactly did you guys go? Oh, Malley's. Why? Her jaw clenched. No reason. Just curious. Was it busy? Pretty dead, actually. Who all was there? Haven't heard their names in a while. The usual.

So I just sit with it, act like I'm over it, pretend like losing people I never thought I'd lose is normal now. Whatever. People come and go, right? But fuck some of them. I really wanted to stay Wakati Huo.

What's actually safe but people think is really dangerous? 1, there has never been a recorded instance of someone using a mobile phone at a petrol pump and there being an explosion. 2, swimming after eating, you won't get cramps. Ask around. Nobody has ever. Three, raw eggs are mostly fine for you. It's not impossible, but you're highly unlikely to get salmonella from eating them. The reason you shouldn't eat raw cookie dough is the raw flour, which is actually dangerous, not the raw eggs. Four, paper wasps. They're incredibly docile. Every year they build a nest above my back door. Even if there's dozens of them swarming around, they won't bother you if you don't bother them. They're fascinating creatures to observe. You can actually feed them by hand by dipping your finger in syrup, honey or anything sugary. They'll lick it right off. Five years of coexisting with them and I have yet to get stung. Plus, having their nest over the door deters burglars. 5, nuclear power, the safest energy source humanity has ever known. Fun nuclear fact, if you swam near the surface of a nuclear containment pool with actual glowing radioactive spent fuel rods in the bottom, you would receive less radiation than if you just stood out in the sun. 6, not that I would know, but apparently and scientifically, taking LSD in a reasonable dose and many other psychedelics, it is almost no risk for physical or mental addiction harm, according to Medical and psychological studies. On the other hand, there are a lot of potential benefits regarding mental health, especially if you compare it with legal stuff like cigarettes or alcohol, which are both one of the most harmful substances in existence. But most people think psychedelics are on the same level as real hard stuff such as meth or heroin just because they only classify in legal and illegal. This is no advice, just my opinion based on a ton of research. 7, eating food that's a bit past the sell by date. 8, msg. And it's so good. Put that on your eggs.
