Well, I stood there staring at my lifeline sitting just three feet away behind that locked glass. I begged him to open it and explained I had maybe 15 minutes before my throat completely closed. But he looked at the packed dining room and said, if you can talk, you can work. Now table 12 needs refills. Go. My face was swelling like a balloon and customers were starting to stare as I struggled to pour water with shaking hands while my throat got tighter with each breath. I stumbled back to Craig wheezing that I needed the Epipen right now. And he actually laughed saying, what are you gonna do, die on me? During the rush, a woman at table 6. Grabbed my wrist when she saw the hive spreading up my neck and said I needed help immediately. But Craig stepped between us, announcing that any customer who encouraged staff histrionics would be asked to leave. My coworker tried to grab the cabinet keys from his belt, and he fired her on the spot in front of everyone, saying, anyone else want to join her in the unemployment line? I couldn't breathe through my nose anymore and my tongue was so swollen I couldn't speak clearly. But I kept serving bread and taking orders because I was a single mom with no savings and Craig knew it. An older man at the bar stood up and offered to drive me to the hospital him, but Craig threatened to call the police for interfering with staff, and the man sat back down looking horrified. By the time I tried to take Table Fifteen's order, I was making horrible wheezing sounds. The mother at the table was crying, saying, please, somebody help her. But Craig just stood there with his arms crossed watching me struggle. My eyes were so puffy I could barely see. And a teenage bus boy tried to sneak me some Benadryl from his pocket, but Craig saw him and sent him home immediately. I made one more desperate attempt to reach the cabinet, but my vision was going black and Craig actually stepped in front of it saying, you walk off this floor or, and you're done here. Forever. That's when something inside me snapped and I grabbed a water pitcher from the server station and smashed it straight through the glass cabinet. Customers gasped around me and Craig screamed that I was fired. My hands were bleeding from the glass, but I managed to grab my Epipen and jam it into my thigh right there in the middle of the dining room while Craig yelled about destruction of property and how I'd have to pay for the damage. The medication gave me just enough relief to gasp out to the packed restaurant. He tried to kill me rather than let me treat my allergic reaction. Before I collapsed onto the floor, a woman who'd been recording everything on her phone called 9 1 1 while Craig actually tried to grab the phone from her, saying, we handle emergencies internally. But three male customers physically blocked him from getting near me. The paramedics arrived within minutes and immediately started additional treatment because as one explained to the growing crowd of customers, Epipens are just a temporary fix. He still needs immediate medical intervention. As they loaded me onto the stretcher, Craig had the audacity to tell them I was being dramatic. And one of the EMTs turned to him and said loud enough for everyone to hear, she would have been dead in 5 more minutes. The entire restaurant erupted with customers screaming at Craig while he tried to escape to his office. But a group of them Blocked his path until police arrived. The detective who interviewed me at the hospital said 14 customers had provided videos and statements, with one recording capturing Craig saying, what are you gonna do, die on me during the rush. The state board revoked Craig's food service license permanently and the judge at his sentencing called him a sadistic individual who weaponized his authority before giving him two years in prison plus three years probation.

My 6 year old son went to Disney with my ex wife, her new husband and her parents. My phone rang. This is Disney staff. Your child is at lost and found. My heart stopped. What happened? Your son says his family told him to wait by the Mad Tea Party while they got fast passes. That was four hours ago. He's been asking every cast member where his mommy went. Four hours. My hands were shaking as I called my ex immediately. Where's Carter? Oh, he's fine. We're back at the Grand Floridian pool. Kids his age get tired of rides anyway. Her voice was slurred. She'd been drinking since lunch. You left him at the park alone. She sighed like I was being overdramatic. Relax, James. Disney's literally the safest place on earth. He'll figure it out. Besides, we paid good money for this adult. It's only vacation adults only. He's your son. Look, Paul wanted to do the grown up rides without a whining kid slowing us down. Carter can handle a few hours by himself. Builds character. We're not helicopter parents like you. I was two states away in Chicago on a business trip. The next flight to Orlando wasn't until 6:00am and every earlier flight was completely booked. Sir, the Disney employee continued, we can keep him overnight in our Family Services center, but we need proper documentation and emergency contacts. He's asking for you specifically. That's when I remembered something that made my blood Boil. Last month, my ex had posted all over Facebook and Instagram about planning her child free Disney adult experience with her new husband. Photos of expensive cocktails at Victoria and Albert's, captions like finally doing Disney the right way. No kids, no stress. She'd even joined Facebook groups about Disney without children and posted countdown photos. She'd literally advertised her plan to abandon our son for a booze filled vacation while still on the phone with Disney security. I started screenshotting everything. Her posts, the time stamps, comments from friends encouraging her adults only Disney trip, her recent check ins at Disney bars during park hours. I sent it all to my lawyer before I even hung up. I'm flying down tonight. I told the cast member, please don't let him out of your sight. I'll cover any costs. Disney employees voice softened. Sir, we take care of our guests. Carter's safe with us. By the time I landed at MCO at 7:00am, my ex was facing criminal child abandonment charges. Turns out leaving a six year old completely alone at a theme park for over four hours isn't just terrible parenting, it's a class 3 felony in Florida. The Orange County Sheriff's Office had already visited her hotel room at 5:00am. The local news picked up the story by noon. Mother abandoned 6 year old at Disney World for adult experience with new husband. The footage of her being LED away in handcuffs from the Grand Floridian lobby. Went viral within hours. Her employer, Orlando General Hospital, saw the coverage during their morning staff meeting. Her nursing license got immediately suspended pending a full investigation. Hard to trust someone with patience when they can't even keep track of the.

I leaked fake baby names to family. So I'm like 6 months pregnant and my husband Kyle and I have been keeping our baby name super secret. We've picked Emmitt for a boy and Nora for a girl. But every single family gathering turns into this crazy interrogation session about what we're naming the kid. My mother in law, Janet, is the worst. She'll literally corner me by the kitchen sink and be like, just give me a hint, honey. I promise I won't tell anyone. Meanwhile, she's already told half the neighborhood that I'm having twins because she misheard something at dinner three weeks ago. Then there's my sister Emma, who keeps suggesting names like Braxton and Nivea because apparently normal names aren't creative enough anymore. And don't even get me started on Kyle's brother who keeps pushing for family names. He wants us to name our kid after their dead Uncle Mortimer. Like, dude, it's 2025, not 1825. The breaking point was last Sunday at my in law's house. I'm trying to eat my potato salad in peace when Janet goes, I have a feeling it's going to be Theodore. Doesn't she look like she's carrying a Theodore? And then Emma chimes in with, no way. That baby is definitely a Paisley. Meanwhile, Kyle's cousin starts going on about how we should honor the family tradition and Kyle's dad is nodding along like this is some kind of democracy vote. I looked at Kyle across the table and He had this look like he wanted to crawl under the furniture. That's when I decided enough was enough. So I stood up, put my hands on my belly, all dramatic like and announced, you know what, you guys have been so invested in this, I think you deserve to know. Everyone got quiet real fast. We've narrowed it down to three names, I said, making eye contact with each person. For a boy, we're thinking either Bartholomew, Nebuchadnezzar or Gaylord. And for a girl, it's between Brunilda, Bertha or Methuselah. Kyle nearly choked on his iced tea. Janet's face went completely white. Emma just stared at me with her mouth hanging open like she'd seen a ghost. Brunilda, Janet whispered, like the opera. It's very traditional, I said, completely straight faced, European heritage and all that. The room was dead silent for like 10 seconds. Then Kyle's brother goes, Gaylord. Are you serious right now? It's a perfectly respectable name. Kyle jumped in, catching on. Very distinguished. What happened next was beautiful chaos. Janet immediately started googling how to talk your daughter in law out of terrible baby names. Emma was frantically texting me links to normal name lists. Kyle's dad kept muttering Nebuchadnezzar under his breath like he was trying to practice saying it. For the next three weeks, I got calls every single day. Janet would call with alternative suggestions like Theodore or Michael. Emma sent me a 47 item list of actually cute names that aren't Completely insane. Even Kyle's normally quiet aunt called to tell me about a nice couple she knew who named their daughter brunhilda. And she got teased terribly in school. The best part was watching them try.

Am I wrong for revealing that my brother's wife is a homewrecker over a mean prank she played on me? My brother Jordan married Nicole last year after a whirlwind romance. She always acted sweet around family, but something about her felt off to me, like she was performing rather than being genuine. I work as a barista at Grind Coffee, a local shop downtown. It's not glamorous, but I love the regular customers, and my manager, Kevin, is pretty cool about everything. Nicole knows where I work, but. And she doesn't. Every Tuesday, Nicole comes in with her book club friends. They order complicated drinks, leave messes, and tip poorly. Nicole acts like she's never seen me before in her life, which is weird, but whatever. I figured she was embarrassed about her brother in law being a coffee shop worker. Last Tuesday changed everything. Nicole walks in around two PM, but not with her book club. She's with this tall guy in an expensive suit, definitely not my brother. They're all over each other, kissing at the counter, his hands all over her waist. She's giggling like a teenager. I'm making their drinks, trying to process what I'm seeing. This woman is married to my brother, wearing her wedding ring, and making out with a stranger in public. Then she turns around and sees me behind the espresso machine. Her face goes completely white. She quickly steps away from the guy, starts acting normal, but it's too late. I saw everything. They order their drinks without making eye contact with me. Nicole whispers something to the guy and they leave quickly. I'm standing there in shock, not sure what to do with this information. The next morning, I get a call from Kevin before my shift. Hey, we need to talk when you get in. Someone filed a complaint about you. My Spino drops at work. Kevin explains that a cuss banner called corporate claiming I was unprofessional, rude, and made inappropriate comments about her personal life. I'm getting an official write up. I know immediately it was Nicole. She's trying to get me fired before I can tell Jordan what I saw. It's actually kind of smart in a twisted way. But here's the thing about our coffee shop. We have security cameras everywhere. Kevin installed them after some theft issues last year. And Kevin's been managing for 10 years. He knows when cuss there are lying. I explain the whole situation to him. How Nicole is my sister in law, how I saw her cheating, and how now she's trying to destroy my job to silence me. Kevin listens without judgment. Wanna see what really happened? He asks, pulling up yesterday's footage on his computer. There it is, clear as day. Nicole walking in with mystery man. Them kissing passionately by the windows. Her wedding ring glinting in the sunlight as she runs her fingers through his hair. Me behind the counter, professional the entire time. Never saying a word to them, Kevin watches the whole thing, then deletes the plaint from corporate system. This never happened, he says, printing out still frames from the video. But you might want these. Family dinner is this Sunday at our parents house. Nicole shows up in a new dress, acting extra sweet to everyone. She keeps glancing at me nervously throughout the meal. During dessert, she leans over with fake concern. How's work going, honey? No problems with difficult cause banners, I hope. You know how some people can be so unreasonable. The whole table is listening. My parents love Nicole. Think she's perfect for Jordan. My brother is completely clueless, cutting his cake with a smile. I smile back at her. Actually works been really interesting lately. We had the situation yesterday with a married woman who came in with her boyfriend. Really awkward when she realized her husband's sister worked there. The table goes quiet. Forks stop moving. Jordan looks confused, glancing between me and Nicole. What do you mean? Jordan asks slowly. Nicole's face is red now. She's just making things up. You know how dramatic she can be. I pull out my phone, show Jordan the security footage still frames Kevin printed for me. This is from Tuesday at two PM. Recognize anyone? Jordan takes the photos, his face changing as he processes what he's seeing. Nicole in another man's arms, kissing him passionately, her wedding ring visible in every shot. Who is this Guy Jordan's voice is barely a whisper. Nicole starts screaming that I'm lying, that the photos are fake, that I'm jealous of their marriage and trying to destroy it. She's

I kicked my boyfriend's parents out of our apartment after his mom called me a bitch. His parents showed up at our door in March without even asking. His mom literally called and told me they were coming to wait out quarantine at our place. Like, not asked, told me. And I already knew this was gonna suck because they've always treated me like garbage. They make these snide comments about everything I do, act like they own the place, and basically think I'm not good enough for their precious son. Right from day one, they started running our apartment like it was theirs. They tell me what to cook, when to clean, how loud my music could be. But the worst part was the stupid air conditioning fight that went on for weeks. It's been like 85 degrees every single day here, and I keep the AC at 70 because that's comfortable, but nope. They started whining about being cold, so I compromised and put it at 75. I'm already sweating my butt off, but whatever. I'm trying to keep the peace. That wasn't good enough, though. They wanted the heat on in 90 degree weather. The heat. I'd wake up in the middle of the night, literally drenched in sweat because they'd sneak over and crank the thermostat up to, like, 80 degrees. I told them to stop messing with it probably 20 times, but they kept doing it anyway. So yesterday morning before work, I grabbed a Roll of duct tape and put, like, 10 pieces over the thermostat. I even wrote a note that said, do not touch the thermostat while I am at work. In big letters. Pretty clear, right? I get home at six PM, and it hits me like a wall of heat the second I open the door. It's hotter inside than it is outside, which shouldn't even be possible. The duct tape is ripped off, my note is crumpled up on the floor, and they've got the heat cranked to 98 freaking degrees. 98! I checked the thermostat three times because I couldn't believe it. I marched straight to the guest room, where they're just chilling like nothing happened. His mom is sitting there filing her nails, and his dad is watching some cooking show. I'm like, dripping sweat already, and I go, why could you not follow the simple instruction of do not touch the thermostat? This is my home! I'm tired of you saying rude things to me. I'm tired of you treating me like a child and making your own rules for my apartment. You either need to respect me and my boundaries or go back to your own house. Mom doesn't even look up from her nails at first. Then she gets this nasty look on her face and says, you have no right to barge in here without knocking. That was not only an invasion of privacy, but you need to take the attitude out of Your tone. I've dealt with much bigger bitches than you before. That's when I completely lost it. She called me a bitch in my own apartment, after I let them stay here for free, after I've been bending over backwards trying to make them comfortable, after they've been treating me like dirt for months. She kept going on and on for, like, 30 minutes about how disrespectful I am and how I need to learn my place and all this other garbage. I just stood there letting her dig her own grave. When she finally shut up, I looked at both of them and said, get out. Pack your stuff and get out of my apartment right now. His dad tried to jump in, like, now hold on. Let's all calm down here, but I cut him off. No, you heard what she said. She called me a bitch in my own home. Get out! They started arguing that they had nowhere else to go and that I was being dramatic. I told them that wasn't my problem and they had one hour to pack their bags before I called the cops. His mom started crying and saying I was ruining their family, but I was done.

I won millions in the lottery and decided not to tell anyone. I asked my family for help as a test. Three weeks ago, I bought a lottery ticket at the gas station on my way home from work. I always buy one when the Jackpot gets big, just for fun. Never expected anything to come of it. Tuesday morning, I'm drinking coffee and checking the numbers on my phone. I had to look at my ticket five times before it sank in. All six numbers matched $47 million. After taxes, I'd still walk away with about 28 million. I sat there staring at that ticket for an hour, shaking. My first instinct was to call my brother Mike and tell him everything. We've been close our whole lives, or so I thought. But then I remembered something that happened last month. My sister Lisa needed 200 bucks to fix her car. She called Mike first, and he told her he was broke, even though I saw him post pictures of his new golf clubs the same week. She ended up calling me crying, saying she felt like a burden on the family. That's when I got an idea. What if I tested everyone before revealing my win? I wanted to see who really cared about me versus who just saw me as the family ATM. I started small. I called my mom and told her my landlord was raising my rent by $300, and I didn't know how I'd make it. Work. She sighed and said money was tight for everyone these days. Then she started talking about her cruise plans for next month. Next, I texted Mike saying my car needed a new transmission and the repair would cost $800. He left me on read for two days, then finally responded saying he wished he could help, but had his own bills to worry about. I called my sister Lisa and told her I was behind on my electric Bill and might get my power shut off. She immediately said she'd send me $50, which was probably all she had. She even offered to let me stay at her tiny apartment if I needed to. The real test came when I called my dad. I told him I was having trouble making my student loan payments and asked if he could help with just one month. He laughed and said I should have thought about that before dropping out of business school 10 years ago. But then I called my cousin Danny, who I barely talk to anymore. I told him the same story about the student loans. Without hesitation, he said he'd send me $200 and asked if I needed more. He said family looks out for family, no matter what. The results were eye opening. Parents and Mike, who always acted like they cared so much, couldn't be bothered to help when I supposedly needed it most. But Lisa and Danny, who don't have much money themselves, were Ready to give me whatever they could. Yesterday, I called Lisa and Danny and asked them to meet me for dinner. I had something important to tell them. They both showed up worried, probably thinking something was wrong. I pulled out my phone and showed them a screenshot of my bank account. Lisa's jaw dropped and he just started laughing and said he knew something was up because I never asked for help. I explained the whole test and told them they were the only ones who passed. Lisa started crying happy tears, and Danny kept shaking his head in disbelief. Then I told them the best part. I was giving each of them $500,000, no strings attached. Lisa could finally go back to nursing school like she'd always wanted. Danny could start the food truck business he'd been dreaming about. My parents and Mike still don't know about the money. And honestly, after seeing their true colours, I'm not sure they ever will. Sometimes the people who claim to love you the most are the first ones to abandon you when you need help. But the people who show up for you when you have nothing. Those are the ones worth sharing everything with.

I told my parents I won't change my name because of their regret. When I was 18, I changed my name to Alex. My real name was Angel Martinez. The name of my brother who died when I was 5. He was eight. We were playing by the street. I kicked our ball too hard. He ran after it. The driver didn't see him in time. At the funeral, mom couldn't stop screaming. Dad just stared at me with dead eyes. That night, they packed away all my toys. The next morning, mom called me Angel at breakfast. That's not my name, I said. Dad slapped the table so hard, the plates jumped. It is now. They moved me into Angel's room that day. His clothes became mine. His backpack, toys. When school started, they told everyone there was a mistake on the records. I wasn't me anymore. I was Angel. My friends stopped coming over when mom kept calling me by his name. Teachers looked worried but did nothing. Every night, I'd whisper my real name under the covers. So I wouldn't forget who I was. On Angel's birthday, they made me wear his favorite shirt. And blow out candles on his favorite cake. Make the wish Angel would have made, mom said, her eyes far away and scary. When I was 12, I found the box where they hid all the pictures of me. The real me. Before. In every family photo after the accident, I was dressed Like him standing where he used to stand. It's like I never existed at all. I started failing school on purpose. Angel got straight A's. I got F's. Angel was good at sports. I quit every team. You're ruining his future, dad would yell. He doesn't have a future! I screamed back. Once mom slapped me so hard, my lip bled. I was 16. I ran away for three days. The police brought me back. The officer asked my name, and I said, my real one. Mom started crying. He's confused. He's Angel. Our son, Angel. The day I turned 18, I took all the money I'd saved for my fast food job and filed the papers to be Alex. Not my birth name. A new name. Someone who wasn't me or him. When the papers came, mom locked herself in Angel's room. My room. And tore all his clothes to pieces. Dad showed up at my friend's house where I was staying. Your mother tried to hurt herself last night, he said, his voice hollow. She says, we lost both sons now. You lost angel when he died, I said. You lost me when you tried to bring him back. Last week, mom called for the first time in months. We're selling the house, she said. Do you want his things? Your things? I don't even know anymore. Burn it all, I said. Yesterday I found a box on my doorstep. Inside was a small blue teddy bear. I'd Never seen before. The note just said this was yours before. I'm sorry we made you disappear, too. I held that bear and cried for the first time since Angel died. For him. For me. For the family that died on that street. Even though only one of us was hit. I am Alex now. Not Angel. Not my old self. Someone new who finally gets to exist.

I told my sister in law no one cares that she's pregnant. My cousin Rachel just buried her husband and two kids last week. Car accident took them all at once. She's left with just her 5 year old daughter Emma. And honestly, watching them at the funeral was the most heartbreaking thing I've ever seen in my life. So my brother Jake and his wife Kelly show up to our house that morning before we head to the church. First thing Kelly does is announce she's pregnant. We're all getting ready for a funeral. And she's like, guess what, everyone, we have news. My mom congratulated her but told her to keep it quiet for today out of respect. Did Kelly listen? Of course not. The second we get to the church, Kelly starts making these loud gagging noises and rubbing her completely flat stomach. Every time someone looked at her, she'd go, oh, sorry, morning sickness, I'm pregnant. You know, she kept saying stuff like, as a mom, I just can't imagine what Rachel's going through, which was ridiculous because Kelly doesn't have any kids yet. At the cemetery, she literally asked Rachel's sister to give up her seat so the pregnant lady could rest her feet. She'd been standing for like 10 minutes total. I was getting so annoyed, but I kept my mouth shut because it's a funeral. After the service, we went back to my aunt's house. Kelly kept making everything about herself. Someone would Mention how hard this must be for Rachel. And Kelly would jump in with, oh, I know. Now that I'm pregnant, I understand maternal instincts so much better. When people were talking about the babies who died, Kelly would rub her stomach and talk about how excited she was to be a mom. The bathroom thing was what really got me. Every time Kelly needed to use the bathroom, she'd announce pregnant lady coming through or baby on board needs to pee there. We're like 30 people there grieving and she's treating it like her personal pregnancy announcement party. But then she crossed the line. Rachel was sitting quietly in the corner with Emma, both of them just completely destroyed. Kelly walks right up to them, sticks out her flat belly and says, me and Jake just found out I'm pregnant. And honestly, we're beside ourselves thinking about how something like this could happen to us, too. Rachel completely broke down, started sobbing so hard she could barely breathe. Emma got scared and started crying, too. Everyone in the room just stopped and stared. That's when I lost it. I stood up and said loud enough for everyone to hear, Kelly, no one gives a damn that you're pregnant. Look around you. This is a funeral for two babies and their father. You took that pregnancy test 4 days ago and you're acting like you're the first woman to ever get pregnant. Just leave. Kelly started crying and ran out. Jake followed her, but not before calling me a fat, bitter witch in front of everyone. My aunt had to comfort Rachel while my mom took Emma outside. My phone's been blowing up all day with calls from Jake and Kelly's family calling me every name in the book. They're saying I.

My brother in law told me cooking was women's work, so I made sure he only did men's work for the rest of his stay. I'm preparing the house for Christmas and already exhausted from years of this exact conversation. Last Thanksgiving, my father in law sat at the table while I served everyone saying, this is how it should be. Women have that special touch in the kitchen. Easter before that, my husband's uncle laughed when I carried in all the dishes alone. Better you than me, sweetheart. I don't do domestic work. My own brother visits monthly and has never once touched a dish, just leaves them by the sink like I'm housekeeping. He once actually said, at least you're good at something while I cleared his plate. Even my husband used to do it until I trained that out of him. It only took 3 years of patient conversations. Now his brother is arriving for Christmas week because his girlfriend finally got tired of being his maid and kicked him out. My front door slams open. His bags hit my clean floor. MUD tracks across my freshly mopped tiles. He's standing there actually watching me on a ladder, hanging Garland, both my hands full and says, what's for dinner? I smile at him the way I've smiled that every man in this family who thinks I exist to clean up after them, he doesn't notice. It never reaches my eyes. Christmas Eve and I've been cooking since 5 in the morning for 12 people. My brother in law has been on my couch eating and chips and watching TV for three days straight, hasn't offered to help once. I ask him sweetly to peel potatoes, he actually laughs at me. Not a chuckle, a full belly laugh. That's women's work. I don't do kitchens. I keep my voice light and ask him to at least set the table. He shakes his head like I'm a child who doesn't understand basic concepts. Like I said, women's work. That's why my brother married you, to handle all this. He gestures at my kitchen like it's some foreign country he'll never visit. My husband walks in right as his brother is explaining how his ex did everything wrong, how she got lazy about cooking, stopped keeping the house properly, couldn't even manage a simple pot roast after coming home from work. Women these days don't understand their role, he says. I watch my husband's face change. His jaw tightens. His brother doesn't notice because he's too busy educating me about how kitchens are female territory. I smile, my real smile this time. You're absolutely right. How silly of me to ask. I shouldn't have expected you to lower yourself to women's work. 5 a. M. Christmas morning, I wake him up with a shovel. There's two feet of snow in the driveway. That's men's work, I say in my sweetest voice. He grumbles but goes out because what's he going To say that shoveling isn't gendered. While he's outside, I make and eat breakfast, eggs, bacon, fresh pancakes for me and my husband. Only he comes in frozen and sees an empty table. Where's my breakfast? I tilt my head, confused. Cooking is women's work, you said, I couldn't possibly expect you to lower yourself to eating something from the. He looks at my husband for support. My husband is suddenly very interested in his coffee. Don't look at me. I made the eggs. He's still staring at our empty plates when I pull out a list from my pocket. I've been saving up all the men's work for when we had a man around who doesn't do kitchens. I made you a list of man's work. I suddenly remember all kinds of things that needed done around the house. The gutters need cleaning. The garage needs reorganizing. All men's work, I keep saying sweetly. He tries. Order.
NA
NA

video_description: I canceled my sister's entire wedding when she uninvited me for looking too good.(3)
voice_to_text: Was doing a five tier for the price of three. I also canceled the two surprises I planned as a gift. I've been secretly paying for the premium open bar package. And upgraded their honeymoon suite to the penthouse. All in all, I was covering about $8,000 worth of upgrades she didn't even know about. Each vendor I call is shocked when I explain this situation. The cake baker actually says, after everything you've done for her. But I just tell them I need to cancel, and they all understand. Some of them even refuse to work with her if she tries to. The venue calls her three days later to confirm cancellation. That's when my phone starts going off crazy. 47 missed calls in an hour. When I finally answer, she's hyperventilating. What did you do to my wedding? She screams so loud, I have to hold the phone away from my ear. The venue wants $12,000 for a last minute booking. The florist won't even return her calls. The photographer is booked. The caterer says they have no record of her event. I let her rant for a solid minute before I calmly explained that all those vendors were my connections, my accounts, my negotiations. You said you didn't want anything from me, remember? She starts sobbing about how the wedding is in 11 days and everything is ruined, and how could I do this to her? You literally told me not to come. I reminded her these Were all my favors to call in, not yours? She tries to guilt trip me, saying I'm ruining the most important day of her life. Frisa, you said good. When I told you I'd have to cancel everything, you hung up on me. She calls me a jealous bitch and says she'll never forgive me. That's fine, I tell her.

video_description: I canceled my sister's entire wedding when she uninvited me for looking too good.(2)
voice_to_text: Made it into this whole family drama. But honestly, if she really felt that threatened by me just existing in a bridesmaid dress, then fine. I told her, okay, if that's what you want. She sounded surprised, like she expected me to beg or cry or something. That night, I started going through all my emails. Every vendor communication is in my inbox because I'm the one who's been handling everything. The venue, that's my boss's country club and he gave us the friends and family discount. The florist, she, the client from my job, the photographer, charging $2,000 instead of his usual $6,000. I designed his entire website portfolio for free last year. The caterer, the DJ, the bartenders, even the hair and makeup team, they're all doing this as favors to me, not her. My sister has no idea that every single contract is technically under my name. The next morning, I called Brisa one more time. Just so you know, if I'm not part of the wedding, I'll need to cancel all the arrangements I made through my connections. She immediately snaps back, good, I don't want anything from you. Anyway, she hung up before I could say anything. I don't think she had any clue what that meant. I spent the rest of that day making calls. First, the venue. I explained that I won't be attending the wedding anymore, so I need to cancel the reservation I made. My boss is confused but says no. Problem next, the florist. She's actually offended when I tell her what happened and says she wouldn't work with my sister now, even if she begged. The photographer is booked solid and happily takes another wedding for that date at his full rate. One by one, I cancel everything, the caterer, the DJ, the cake baker.

I told my fiance we should call the wedding off if she doesn't approve of my female best man. So back in March, I proposed to my girlfriend, Jasmine. Everything was going great until we started talking about wedding planning this week. He already picked her bridesmaids and was asking about my groomsmen, trying to figure out who'd walk with who down the aisle. I told her my best man was actually going to be my friend, Kate. The second I said that, Jasmine completely lost it. He started listing off all these ridiculous reasons why Kate couldn't do it. She said it would look weird in photos, that it'd be awkward when Kate walks down the aisle with her maid of honor, that Kate would be too distracting to the guests. And get this, that Kate's too short to stand next to my 6 foot plus groomsman. I mean, what the hell? I told her those reasons were stupid and she got mad at me for not respecting her wishes. She started throwing out suggestions for other guys who could be my best man instead. But here's the thing, Kate's been my closest friend since grad school. He literally introduced me to my entire Social Circle when I was this awkward, nerdy guy who couldn't make friends to save his life. She's been there through everything, good times and bad. Not having her in my wedding felt insane. Jasmine kept pushing, getting more accusatory about why I wanted Kate there. So badly. She was acting like there was something between us, which there isn't. Kate and I have never been romantic or sexual, not even close. We're just really good friends and Jasmine used to be totally fine with that. The argument got heated. Jasmine wouldn't budge and kept acting completely irrational about the whole thing. I could tell the real issue was jealousy, but I wasn't gonna just give into her insecurities. Finally, I told her that if she couldn't let me have this one thing, maybe we shouldn't be getting married at all. She exploded, told me to get out of our apartment immediately. I've been crashing on my buddy Matt's couch for the past three days now. Yesterday I tried calling Jasmine to talk things through, but she just asked if I was ready to apologize. I I told her no because I'm not going to let her think she was right about forbidding me from having Kate in the wedding. The thing is, Kate doesn't even know about any of this drama yet. She was so excited when I first asked her to be my best man a few weeks ago. She actually teared up and said it meant everything to her. We've been through so much together. She helped me study for the MCAT when I was failing. She drove me to the hospital when I broke my arm skateboarding like an idiot. She was there when my mom died two years ago. She's basically Family to me. But Jasmine's acting like Kate's some kind of threat, which is weird because they've known each other for over a year now. And Jasmine seemed cool with our friendship before. They're not best friends or anything, but they've hung out, gone to dinner together, seemed to get along fine. I thought Jasmine had gotten over any jealousy issues about me having a close female friend.

What screams I've never been poor to you. I was standing in line at the grocery store with my nine year old son Jake holding a single bag of flour. That's all we could afford that week, just flour to make some basic bread. When I swiped my E B t card, the machine beeped red, declined. My face burned with embarrassment as I asked the cashier if I could try again. Jake was holding the flower bag against his chest looking confused. Machine beeped again, declined. Behind me, this man in an expensive suit started getting loud. He had a Bluetooth headset in his ear and was tapping his credit card against his hand like he was in some huge rush. Seriously, this is ridiculous, he said loud enough for everyone to hear. Some people really need to get their act together before coming to the store. I tried one more time with the card, my hands shaking. Jake tugged on my sleeve and whispered, mom, what's wrong? The machine beeped a third time. The man behind me got even louder. This is exactly what's wrong with this country. People living off government handouts can't even manage their own money properly. Other customers started staring. I could feel their eyes burning into me. Jake looked around at all the faces, then down at his shoes. Maybe if you got a real job instead of mooching off taxpayers, you could actually pay for your groceries. The man continued, I work 60 hours a week and have to wait behind people who can't even afford a bag of flour. I didn't say anything back. I couldn't. I just took the flower from Jake's hands, put it on the counter and walked out. Jake followed me, asking if we were coming back for it later. Two days later, I got called into HR. At the law firm where I worked as a receptionist. My manager sat me down and said there had been a complaint about my behavior reflecting poorly on the company. When I asked what she meant, she said a senior client had recognized me, causing a scene at a grocery store. But I didn't cause any scene. I told her I just left when my card didn't work. He pulled out her phone and showed me a video. Someone had filmed the whole thing. You could see me standing there quietly while the man behind me yelled about government handouts and taxpayers. You could see Jake looking embarrassed and confused. Our client sent this to us. She said he felt it was important we know about this incident. I, I stared at the video in shock. I was just trying to buy flower for my son. It's about optics, Maria. This firm has a reputation to maintain. We can't have employees who, well, who create these kinds of situations in public, create situations. I didn't say a single word to that man, but it didn't matter. They let me. Go that afternoon just like that. No warning, no second chance. They said it was about maintaining the firm's image. A week later, Jake was playing with my phone when he started laughing. Mom, there's a video of you on here. Someone had posted the grocery store incident on TikTok. But this time, the comments were completely different.

I threatened to ban my brother from my wedding because he plans on proposing to his girlfriend during the reception. So I'm getting married next month to my girlfriend, Emma. And honestly, it's been the most stressful thing I've ever planned. We've been saving for two years, booked this amazing venue, and Emma's been dreaming about this day since we got engaged. She has this Pinterest board with like 500 pins of centerpieces and table settings. About three weeks ago, I was over at my brother Tyler's place helping him fix his sink. He's five years older than me and has always been the golden child in our family. While I was under the sink with a wrench, he casually asks if it would be cool if he proposed to his girlfriend, Becca, at our wedding reception. I literally banged my head on the pipe. I came out laughing because I thought he was joking. I said something like, yeah, sure, if you want Emma to murder you with her cake knife. We both laughed it off and I figured that was the end of it. Then last Tuesday, Emma comes home from work crying, like full on sobbing in our kitchen. She tells me Tyler called her and thanked her for letting him propose at the wedding. Emma was confused and told him that never happened and he absolutely couldn't do that. Tyler just laughed and said thanks again before hanging up. I was furious. I called Tyler immediately. And he picks up all casual like nothing happened. I asked what the hell he was thinking. That's when he drops this bomb about how he's getting even with me because I announced our engagement at a family dinner where he was introducing Becca to everyone for the first time. The thing is, I had no clue he was bringing her that night. They showed up separately and she arrived like 20 minutes after I made the announcement. I didn't even know they were serious at that point. Tyler kept insisting he was going to propose no matter what I said. He had this whole speech prepared about family unity and how romantic it would be. I told him flat out that if he didn't drop this idea completely, both him and Becca were banned from the wedding. If he even tried to pull something like this, security would escort them out. That's when Tyler completely lost it. He started screaming about how I was being selfish and controlling. He hung up on me and immediately called our parents, our aunts and uncles, basically everyone in our family.

When did being a good friend completely backfire? My friend autumn asked me to hang out with her during her overnight shift at the pawn shop there had been three robberies at other shops in the area this month and an employee was killed at the last one. I got there at 9 as the last customer was leaving and autumn was locking the front door, explaining we'd only buzz in people who had items on them. The buzzer went off for the first time at 10:30 when autumn buzzed the man in. He walked up to the counter with this big smile, and he needed quick cash for a family emergency and had electronics to sell. But something felt off about how he kept looking around the shop instead of at us while he talked, memorizing where all the cameras were. While autumn examined his old laptop, the man walked around the shop, stopping at the case with the guns, asking if those were real. Autumn said yes, but they kept them locked, and he nodded, then asked about the jewelry case electronic section, like he was cataloging everything valuable. He came back to the counter and after a minute asked how much cash the shop kept on hand for buying items, when autumn looked up nervously and said it varied. He asked if we knew about Luna, the employee who died last week. The way he knew her name made my skin crawl because it hadn't been Released in the news, Autumn's hands started shaking, and she said, no, we didn't know her. He said that was good, because it would be traumatic to lose a friend that way, bleeding out behind the counter while the safe was being emptied. Neither of us had heard that detail, and autumn asked how he knew that. He smiled and said he paid attention to things. He asked if we were alone in the shop, and when autumn said the owner checked the cameras remotely, he looked directly at each camera and counted them out loud, then said, cameras didn't help Luna. My heart was pounding now as he walked to the back area where the guitars hung, running his hands along them, then to the tool section. Picking up a crowbar and feeling its weight, he brought it back to the counter and set it down, saying it was a nice one, good quality. Could probably open anything with it. He asked autumn if she'd ever been robbed before, and when she said no, he said, Luna probably said the same thing before that night. He leaned across the counter and asked if autumn knew what Luna's mistake was. We. We're both frozen, as he said she'd been too slow opening the safe, had fumbled the combination twice because her hands were shaking, and that made everything take longer than necessary. He said delays were dangerous for everyone involved. Adam's hand moved toward the silent alarm, but he grabbed Her wrist, not hard, but firm. And said Luna had tried that too, but the police took 12 minutes to arrive. He let go and stepped back, say, and he needed to make a withdrawal from the safe. All the cash and the good jewelry from the case. Autumn said she couldn't do that, and he said she could and would, because he'd asked nicely once already. He mentioned that Luna had said she couldn't open the safe either, but eventually she did. It just took some convincing. And unfortunately, the convincing went

video_description: My boyfriend said modern women have ruined relationships, so I gave him the 1950s housewifeÔºà3Ôºâ
voice_to_text: Craig, did you really say that? She's twisting my words, Craig growled. Oh, no. Mister Anderson was very clear. He said women should shut up, stay home and give men sex on demand. The boss's face went ice cold. HR. Will want to discuss this on Monday. Craig. By week 3, Craig was cracking. Can we please have sex? He asked. One night, I gasped, clutching my pearls, literally. Mister Anderson, good girls don't do that before marriage. What would Jesus think we, we have been having sex for three years. That was the old me. The new traditional me saves herself for marriage. He punched a pillow. Then came his mother's birthday dinner at Craig's favorite steakhouse. When the waiter came over, I handed him my menu immediately. Mr Anderson will order for me. Ladies, don't talk to other men. Craig's mom's jaw dropped. Craig, what is going on? Your son wanted a traditional 1950s relationship, I explained. Looking down shyly, he says, modern women ruined everything by having jobs and opinions. Craig, Michael Anderson. His mother's voice could have broken windows. You're trying to control this sweet, successful woman. Mom, she's doing this on purpose. May I speak, Mr Anderson, I asked sweetly. Stop calling me that. But you wanted to be the man of the house. Traditional men are called Mister by their women. His mother yelled at him through the entire dinner while I sat silently asking Craig for permission to eat each bite on the Drive home, he exploded. Fine. I was wrong. Please just go back to normal. I smoothed my dress carefully. Oh, Mr Anderson. A traditional woman never questions her man's first decision. It would not be proper for me to disagree with you. The vein in his forehead looked ready to pop as I smiled sweetly and walked exactly three steps behind him to his apartment door.

video_description: My boyfriend said modern women have ruined relationships, so I gave him the 1950s housewifeÔºà2Ôºâ
voice_to_text: In the 1950s, unmarried couples needed chaperones. I will have to take the bus and meet you there. The bus? Just get in the car. That would make me a loose woman, Mister Anderson. He had to explain to everyone at the party why we arrived separately. At the party, his friend Kyle asked about my promotion. I turned to Craig. May I answer him, Mister Anderson? Craig's face went red. Just talk to him. As you wish. I turn to Kyle. Mr. Anderson doesn't believe women should work. I will be quitting my job soon to focus on cooking and cleaning like a real woman. My mother failed to teach me that my only value is serving a man. Kyle nearly choked on his beer. Dude, what the hell? She's being stupid. Craig muttered, no. Mr. Anderson believes modern women are broken. We think we deserve Equality when we should be grateful men even put up with us. I sat quietly, hands folded, only speaking when Craig gave permission. His friends kept staring at him. The real entertainment started at his come any picnic. When his boss's wife asked about my job, I smiled sweetly. Mr. Anderson says careers make women forget how to be women. Would you like my potato salad recipe instead? It's the only thing I'm good for. I spent the entire event walking three steps behind Craig, staring at the ground, calling him Mr. Anderson and asking his permission for everything. May I have a Hot dog, Mr. Anderson. Just take the damn hot dog. Is that a yes? I need you to say yes or no. His coworkers started whispering. When someone asked why I kept calling him Mr. Anderson, I explained happily. Craig says modern women destroyed society by thinking they're equal to men. He wanted a traditional 19 fifties relationship where I knew my place. His boss

Australian scientists have found a brand new species of this funnel web that is even bigger. How much bigger? Well the standard Sydney funnel web grows to around 5 centimeters or 2 inches and I mean if you're asking me two inches is more than enough. Two inches is actually fucking huge by comparison. This is the new one. It's twice the fucking size cunt. Four inches of eight legged menace to the.

Best friend said I'd always be the ugly one. So I became the one she couldn't compete with. Growing up, Kenzie never let me forget my place in our friendship. Every party, every hangout, every introduction came with the same unspoken rule. I was the designated ugly fat friend who made her shine brighter. This is my friend who's really funny, she'd say, which everyone knew meant not pretty. It hurt every single time. Kenzie was gorgeous. I knew do that. But her constant reminders made me believe I was worthless. Was I really that hideous? When I was 22, something shifted. I needed a physical outlet for my anxiety and found a groupon for a rock climbing gym across town. The first day my hands shook on every hold, but something about solving each route, finding my path up the wall made me feel powerful. That's when I discovered my escape. I started climbing four nights a week in secret. My hands bled, then calcified. I'd ice my forearms after every session, watch technique videos until 2:00am, practice grip strength exercises at my desk. Wednesday and Friday nights, I climbed with the regulars, including this guy, Sebastian, who became my climbing partner. We'd spot each other, celebrate sends, build genuine friendship through shared challenges. I never mentioned him to Kenzie. She wouldn't care about my gym friends anyway. Meanwhile, Kenzie had become obsessed with her marketing firm crush. She constantly prove I was the ugly friend by making me Stand next to her in mirrors, see the difference, she'd say, adjusting her hair. Some people just have it. Others are good listeners. She'd drag me shopping, hold up identical outfits against us both. This would look cute on me. You should stick to black. It's slimming. What killed me was how she document everything on Instagram, always cropping me out or positioning me behind her natural beauty. She caption photos where I was literally holding her phone's ring light. I started wondering if she was right. Maybe I was fooling myself thinking climbing made me worth something. Kenzie's birthday party was approaching. This rooftop bar event she'd been planning for months. She'd invited her entire office, especially her crush. He finally rsvp'd yes, he squealed. I need you there, but like don't talk too much. Just laugh at my jokes and leave early if I give you the signal. The night of the party, she made me wear this shapeless black dress. It's so you, she lied. As guests arrived, she positioned me strategically, visible enough to make her look charitable for having an ugly friend, hidden enough not to distract. Then her crush walked in with three friends. Kenzie grabbed my arm, whispered, remember your wallpaper? But when he scanned the crowd, his eyes stopped on me. His whole face lit up. Oh my god, red, he called out using my climbing nickname. Kenzie froze. Sebastian practically ran over his friends trailing behind. Guys, this is the girl. I've been telling you about the one who sent that impossible 5 11 route last week. He turned to me, eyes bright with genuine excitement. I can't believe you're here. Wait, you know, Kenzie. For the next hour, Sebastian couldn't stop talking about our climbing adventures. He told everyone about the time I helped him overcome his fear of overhangs, how I taught him this specific, the heel hook technique, how watching me climb had made him a better athlete. His friends already knew stories about me. Sebastian had apparently been talking about his badass climbing partner for months. Kenzie stood there, designer dress and perfect make, useless against authentic connection. How long have you been doing this together, someone asked. Six months, Sebastian said, then looked at me with this soft expression. Best six months of my week, every week. Kenzie tried to interject, mentioning the marketing campaign they'd worked on together. Sebastian barely heard her. He was already pulling up videos on his phone showing everyone this route we'd worked on together. His hand naturally finding my shoulder as he narrated our victory. You never told me you climbed, Kenzie said, her voice sharp. You never asked what I did Wednesday and Friday nights, I replied. You just said to stay out of your way. Sebastian looked between us, understanding dawning on his face. Wait.

When I came back from work, I saw my 6 year old daughter standing outside freezing in the snow. I slammed on the brakes and jumped out of my car. Nora, baby, what are you doing out here? She was shivering violently in just her school clothes, no coat, tears frozen on her little cheeks. Daddy locked me out, he said. I can't come back until you get home from work. My heart dropped. It was nine PM on a Friday. Jonathan knew I always worked late on Fridays. This wasn't an accident. How long have you been out here since you left this morning, she whispered. I scooped her up, feeling how ice cold her little body was and carried her toward our front door. It was locked. I used my key, Fury building with every, every step. I found Jonathan exactly where I expected, sprawled on the couch in his boxers and T-shirt, controller in hand, playing call of duty. The heat was cranked up to 75 degrees. Empty beer cans littered the coffee table. Why was our daughter outside for 12 hours? I tried to keep my voice calm. He didn't even pause his game. She spilled grape juice on my new controller this morning. I told her actions have consequences. I stared at him in disbelief. She's 6 years old, Jonathan. She spilled juice accidentally and you left her outside to freeze? Maybe next time she'll be more careful around my stuff. That's when I noticed Nora's pink backpack sitting by the front door. It was stuffed full, bulging at the seams. Her favorite stuffed bunny was sticking out the top. What's this? I pointed at the bag. Jonathan finally paused his game and turned to look at me. There was something cold in his eyes I'd never, ever seen before. I've been doing a lot of thinking today. While she was outside, he said slowly, this whole family thing isn't working out for me, nor is too much work, too expensive, too loud. And honestly, I never wanted kids in the first place. The room started spinning. What are you talking about? I'm talking about you taking her and leaving tonight. I already had the locks changed while you were at work. You just got lucky I hadn't switched them out yet. I felt like I was in a nightmare. You're abandoning your own daughter. Nora was still clinging to me, her wet clothes soaking through my work blazer. She was listening to every word, her big brown eyes darting between us. Here's the thing. Jonathan stood up, stretching like this was all perfectly normal. She's not really mine anyway. I mean, yeah, biologically, whatever, but I never signed up for this dad life. You can have her. The casual cruelty in his voice made me sick. This was the man I've been married to for eight years, the man who used to read Nora bedtime stories. Jonathan, she's your daughter. You can't just watch Me? He picked up his phone. I already talked to my buddy Steven, who's a lawyer. Apparently, if I just voluntarily give up my parental rights, I don't have to pay child support either. Win, win. My hands started shaking, but not from fear, from rage. I pulled out my phone and speed dialed a number I'd hoped I'd never have to use. Hi, Christine. It's Caroline. Remember that emergency custody documentation we.

What is surprisingly illegal? One it's illegal to own more than six intimate toys in Texas. Five is okay, I guess, but you're on thin ice. Two children selling lemonade without a licence. Three in Germany, it's legal to break out of prison, but not in your prison uniform, because that would be stealing. 4. It's illegal to masturbate a butterfly in Missouri. Do what you want with that information. 5. Pleasuring someone via your mouth is technically illegal in South Carolina, although I don't know how it's actually enforced. Six throughout Alabama, it's illegal for a person to walk down the street with an ice cream cone in their back pocket. Back when most people got around on horseback, horse thieves would put ice cream in their pocket to lure horses away without being charged with stealing. 7. It is illegal to parachute inside Saint Peter's Basilica in the Vatican. After a person did it, they had to create that law specifically for him. He walked away, no charge as the law did not exist. Eight in Connecticut, a pickle can't be considered a pickle, nor sold as one, unless it bounces when dropped from the height of one foot in the air. This state regulation was the result of devious pickle packers selling substandard pickles that obviously didn't bounce. Nine if in Western Australia, possessing more than 50 kilograms of potatoes. Yep, you read that correctly. Potatoes. 10 in the most southern island of the Caribbean, Trinidad and Tobago. It's illegal to curse in public 11. Paying expired parking meters that aren't your spot 12. In China, it's illegal to reincarnate without the government's permission 13. In Italy, it's illegal to not have at least one B day installed per home 14. Sleeping in your car 15. In the landlocked state of Nebraska, it is illegal to go wailing.

What's something you did that you later found out was illegal? One, I was travelling and on one leg of the trip, what I thought was a two hour layover was actually a 26 hour wait. I didn't have the right visa to leave the airport and the customs guy said I wouldn't be able to stay overnight. So I asked him if I could buy a visa anywhere at the airport. He gave me a price, but it was in the local currency and I didn't know the exchange rate. The ATM would only dispense USD for an American card. So I took out $100 and went back to the desk. I handed the customs official the money and asked, is this enough? It wasn't until I saw him put it in his pocket before stamping my passport that I realised I had just paid a bride. 2. I scanned a dollar Bill and printed it out. In computer class in seventh grade, the substitute teacher called the cops. An officer showed up, took me in a small room, threw the actual book at me and made me read the entries on counterfeiting aloud. I was super scared, but girls like me a lot more after I got pulled out of class by the police. 3, riding a bike drunk. Apparently that's a DUI. 4, when I was in middle school, my dad would give me $20 a week to pay for much. I was rarely ever hungry at Lunch. So I just ended up saving the money. One day, someone asked to borrow a dollar to buy snacks, and they pay me back with a quarter as interest the following week. I agree and it becomes a thing. Next thing I know, more people are quietly borrowing money from me and paying me back. And it kind of snowballs to the point where I even had teachers borrow money from me once in a while. During this period, I had lamented to my buddies that one or two folks who had borrowed from me often were avoiding me because they couldn't pay me back. Someone offered to collect the money for me if they could keep some of what they got. It sounded like a good deal, so I agreed. I eventually stopped doing it because I felt like people were only using me for my money. I tried to reinvent it myself when I started high school years later, I realized that I had inadvertently been a lone shark. 5 pumped my own gas. New Jersey is an odd place.

Parents, when did you realise your kids actually listen to what you tell them? I taught my daughter about being kind to everyone. I never thought it would save multiple lives. My 15 year old Emma came home last Tuesday acting weird. She kept checking her phone every few minutes and seemed nervous about something. When I asked what was wrong, she just said nothing, mom, and went straight to her room. She barely touched her dinner that night, just pushed the spaghetti around her plate. The next morning she hugged me extra long before school. She never does that anymore. She's usually rushing out the door complaining about being late for first period. I thought maybe she had a big test or presentation. Something felt off, but I couldn't put my finger on it. She even forgot her favorite water bottle on the counter. Around 10:00am, I got a call from the school. My heart stopped when I saw the number pop up on my phone. The Principal's voice was shaky as she said there was an emergency and all parents needed to come to the school immediately. She wouldn't tell me what happened over the phone, which made my panic even worse. I raced to the school and saw police cars everywhere. Ambulances lined the street with their lights flashing. Parents were crying and hugging each other in the parking lot, some still in their pajamas from rushing over. My hands were shaking as I searched frantically for Emma, I found her sitting with a police officer in the main office. The officer asked me to sit down. I knew this couldn't be good news. For the past three weeks, Emma had been sitting with this quiet kid named Marcus at lunch. He always looked sad and.

The priest suddenly stopped the wedding and asked, where is Susie? The bride's name isn't Susie. My best friend Janice was literally mid vow when Father Angelo raised his hand and said, I'm sorry, but I need to ask something. Where is Susie? Everyone in the church went dead silent because we all knew the bride's name wasn't Susie. The groom's face went white and Janice's voice cracked when she said, who's Susie? I stood there as maid of honor, holding her bouquet, watching her eyes fill with tears just thinking her fiance had another woman. An elderly woman in the back stood up and pointed directly at me. That's her! That's Susie! The whole church turned to stare at me, including my best friend Janice. But I was just as confused as everyone was in the room. My mom rushed out of her pew and ran to the altar before the old woman could finish walking down the aisle. Mom grabbed my arm trying to pull me away from the ceremony. We need to leave right now! Janice grabbed my other arm, crying, did you sleep with my fiance? Mom tugged my arm harder. The old woman reached the altar and slam her cane down onto the marble floor with a bang. Please let me speak to my granddaughter in peace before it's too late. The entire congregation whispered with questions and rumors. My mom hissed, stay away from us!

Three men are now in custody as police desperately try to find 15 year old Alisa Petrov. Are you guys keeping up with this story? Alisa is a 15 year old at Utah girl who vanished on April 21st after her mom dropped her off at school or so she thought. Alisa then left the school headed to a gas station and then went to a track station and took a train to Provo. But that's where the cops lost her. So police go to her social media and they start snooping around and see that she's been speaking with a 38 year old man named William Taylor Grinds. And the conversation between the two is very, very sexually charged. So Glynns tells police that yes, he had been speaking to her but no, he's never actually met up with her. And the last time he heard from her was when she sent him a text message from some stranger's phone at a random bus stop in Utah. But then last week police arrest another man 35 year old Matthew Nichols Manard who was also talking to Lisa in a very sexual way. Alisa's iPad shows the conversation between her and Menard are talking about her running away. And Menard says that he'd fly to Vegas to meet up with her but work wouldn't allow him to until late may or early June. Here's where it gets even crazier. Now police have arrested a third man 41 year old Samuel Mitchell And again, conversations are very sexual in nature. Alisa told him that she wanted to run away to Vegas, and he told her that he would help kidnap her if that's what she wanted. Here's what's so scary to me. All three of these men have been charged, but none of them have been charged with anything related to Alisa's disappearance. They're facing charges related to the conversation. So, uh, enticing a minor and sexual exploitation. So if they didn't kidnap her, where is she? Police have also said that these men didn't know each other. It wasn't part of like, a ring. These were all separate conversations with Alyssa.

Charge them the same family rate they charged me. So my kids daycare had some family emergency and shut down for the day. They sent this email at like 3 in the morning, which was real helpful when I'm already asleep and have to work the next day. I'm scrambling around trying to find someone to watch my kid because I literally could not miss work that day. Had this huge presentation that would basically make or break my job. So I'm calling everyone I know at like 6:00am. The only person who picks up is my step brother's girlfriend, Ashley. Doesn't work, just sits around all day while my step brother pays for everything. I mean everything. Her daily Starbucks runs, weekly nail appointments, the whole designer purse collection. been trying to get her to do literally anything productive for years, but whatever, I'm desperate. I call her up and she's like, oh, sure, I can totally watch him for you. I'm thinking, finally, someone's actually gonna help me out. Then she hits me with it. My family rate is $200 for six hours. I literally had to ask her to repeat that because I thought I heard wrong. $200, six hours to watch one kid who mostly just plays with his tablet anyway? Are you being serious right now? I asked. She goes on this whole speech about how this is her livelihood and she takes childcare very seriously and that she's already giving me a family Discount. I'm thinking, what livelihood? You haven't worked a day since you moved in with my stepbrother three years ago. But I'm stuck. If I don't show up to work that day, I'm literally getting fired. So I agree to her insane price, and she demands the money up front. Before I even drop my kid off. I hand over $200 cash, drive to work fuming, and end up working barely four hours after you factor in traffic. So I basically paid 50 bucks an hour for her to sit on her couch and make sure my kid didn't burn the house down. Fast forward two years. Ashley and my step brother break up, but somehow she ends up living rent free in his dad's extra house and driving my dad's old car. My step brother still pays all her bills because they have a kid together. Now. She finally gets a job at some retail place because he stopped funding her weekly spa days. Then last month, I get this panicked text in our family group chat. Emergency. My babysitter bailed and I have to work today or I'll get fired. Can anyone watch my daughter, please? I'm desperate. I'm reading this text, and I can't help but smile a little. I text her back super fast, I can totally help you out. I'll watch her. She's so relieved and grateful, sending me heart emojis and everything. Then I hit her with the kicker. My family rate is $200. For the day. The typing bubbles appear and disappear, like, five times. Then my phone starts blowing up. Are you kidding me right now? That's way too much. I thought we were family. You're being ridiculous. Just screenshot our old conversation from two years ago and send it back to her. This is the exact same rate you charged me. You said it was the family rate, remember? You said you took this very seriously. She completely lost it. Started calling me every name in the book, saying I was petty and vindictive and that she was in a real emergency. I told her that's exactly what I said to her two years ago. The best part? She ended up having to call out of work anyway because nobody else would watch her kid for free on such short notice. And apparently, her manager was not happy about it.

What are some things you'd only know by growing up poor? I Learned how to make a full meal out of whatever was in the back of our kitchen cabinets. My mom called it creative cooking, but really it was just survival. Like when we'd run out of real food by the third week of every month, I got really good at making spaghetti using ramen noodles and ketchup packets from McDonald's. My little brother Jake thought it was a special recipe until he went to his friend's house and saw what actual spaghetti looked like. The worst part was pretending everything was normal at school. When kids talked about going out to eat, I'd nod along like I knew what they meant. Honestly, the only restaurant I've been to was the Soup Kitchen downtown, and that didn't really count. I remember this one time in 4th grade when our teacher asked us to write about our favorite family tradition. Everyone wrote about Christmas morning or birthday parties. I wrote about Cabinet Day, the day every month when mom would dump out all our kitchen cabinets and we'd get creative with whatever expired cans and random ingredients we found. My teacher, Mrs. Rodriguez, kept me after class. She asked if everything was okay at home. I told her Cabinet Day was fun, like a cooking game show. She didn't look convinced, but she let me go. The thing is, you get really good at making stuff work. Like when my Shoes got holes in them. I Learned to put duct tape inside so my socks wouldn't get wet. When our heat got shut off, I figured out that if you left the oven door open, it could warm up the kitchen pretty good. I also got really good at math because I was always counting money. Not like homework math, but real math. Like if milk costs three dollars and we only have two, 50, how many days can we make cereal with water instead? Or if electricity costs sixty dollars and we only have 40, which appliances can we unplug to make it last longer? But the weirdest thing I Learned was how to be invisible at school. Poor kids develop the superpower where we can blend into the background. Like when they were collecting money for field trips, I'd suddenly need to use the bathroom. When they passed out the free lunch forms, pretend to be really interested in my textbook. The free lunch thing was the worst. They'd call out names over the intercom every morning for kids who qualified for free meals. They might as well have announced, here are all the poor kids in school. I started bringing empty lunch bags and pretending to eat air sandwiches just to avoid that walk of shame to the lunch counter. Then something crazy happened. In 6th grade, this new kid, Austin, moved to our school. His family was even worse off than mine. On his second day, When they called the free lunch names, I stood up and said, finally, I'm starving, really loud. Everyone laughed, but not in a mean way. That's when I realized something. I was spending so much energy hiding being poor that I was missing out on actually living. Austin became my best friend because he didn't care who knew his family struggled. He traded his free lunch pizza for my free lunch hamburger without any shame. We started this thing where we have poverty competitions, see who could come up with the most creative poor kids solutions. Like Austin figured out that if you filled up water bottles at school, you could take free drinks home. I discovered that if you ask nicely, the cafeteria ladies would sometimes give you extra rolls to take with you. The best part was when Austin's mom got a new job and they moved to a better apartment. Instead of forgetting about being poor, he invited me over to show me their new place. They had a full refrigerator for the first time in years. His mom made us sandwiches with actual lunch meat instead of government cheese. And Austin looked at me and said, we made it.

The police officer who shoved the pacifier down his baby's throat so forcefully that it caused a brain bleed has been fired from the Portage Police Department. Thirty two year old Cameron Coronado's wife told police their six month old baby was fussy early in the morning. So Cameron got up and took him into the kitchen. The mom said she then heard Cameron shout out, oh my god, shut the F up and then heard the baby's cry change. So mom walks into the kitchen to see what's going on and sees her husband Cameron wiping blood away from the baby's mouth with a baby wipe. She asked Cameron what the hell happened and he says he got frustrated with the baby crying and forced the pacifier down his throat. So Cameron decides to take the baby on a car ride to calm him down. But when they got back 15 minutes later, the baby was still screaming in pain. He wouldn't swallow and he refused to eat. So Cameron's wife asked if they should take the baby to the hospital and Cameron apparently said, quote, I know what will happen to me if we take him. So they end up taking him to the er and the doctor confirms the pacifier was pushed so forcefully down his throat that the first layer of skin had been torn off and the baby had a brain bleed. Mom then told police that things like this have happened before, but she Was afraid to tell anyone because he's a cop. She said once when he was frustrated with their daughter, he squeezed her super tight and then punched a hole in the wall. He also said that on the evening of July 9th, both the kids were fussy and Cameron threatened to, quote, kill these effing kids if they didn't stop crying. Coronato has been fired from his job and charged with child abuse. Bond is set at 10 k.

First red flag. This is the pastor's home. If your pastor lives in a house like this, they were not blessed by god. They are scamming you.
