What's the most insane coincidence that's happened to you? I was 32 when my kidneys basically gave up on me. Just like that. One day I'm fine, next day I'm peeing blood and my face looks like a balloon. Doctor told me I had maybe six months before I'd need a machine to keep me alive, or I wouldn't see Christmas. The dialysis treatments were hell. Three times a week, four hours each time, hooked up to this machine that cleaned my blood because my body couldn't do it anymore. I'd sit there watching Netflix on my phone, listening to other patients talk about their families coming to visit. Meanwhile, I'm sitting alone because my only family disappeared when I was 8. My mom, Karen, literally vanished one Tuesday morning. Left me sleeping and never came back. Foster care, group homes, the whole deal. I used to wonder if she was dead or alive. But after 24 years of nothing, I figured she was probably gone. So when Doctor Martinez told me I needed a kidney transplant and asked about family donors, I just shrugged. It's just me, I said. He put me on the national donor list, but warned me the wait could be years. People my age with my blood type, we weren't exactly priority. Crazy thing is, while I'm sitting in that dialysis chair every Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday slowly dying, Karen was doing the exact same thing. Three states over. Liver failure from years of drinking. And god knows what else. She'd been in and out of jail, living under fake names. Basically destroyed her body completely.

What's the most messed up thing you've seen on a zoom class? Okay, so this happened during 7th grade history when we had this substitute teacher, Mister Ramos. He. He was only supposed to be there for like a week while our regular teacher was sick. Nothing crazy, just some boring guy clicking through slides about the Civil War or whatever. But on Wednesday, something really weird happened that still makes me cringe thinking about it. So class had just ended. Everyone was saying bye and closing their laptops. I was still on the call, though, because me and my friends Aria and Josh always stayed on after to mess around and share TikToks. We'd screen share funny videos and just talk about random stuff. That's when Mister Ramos's camera suddenly came back on. At first we thought maybe he forgot to leave the call, but then we realized he had no idea we were still there. He couldn't see us because our cameras were off. He got up from his desk, took his button down shirt completely off, and lit up a cigarette right there in what looked like his bedroom. Then he opened another laptop next to him and pulled up what looked like a live stream of himself teaching our class from earlier that day. We all just froze like what the hell was happening? He started clicking through this folder on his computer called Zoom Class Recordings and began laughing to himself while watching clips of Us from previous classes. That's when he started talking to himself and saying really messed up stuff about all of us kids. Look at this little girl. Always pretending to care about history. She's probably cheating on every assignment, he said while pointing at the screen. Then he clicked on another video and started making fun of this kid Tyler, who always ask questions. Little Tyler thinks he's so smart, but his parents still cut his food for him. He kept going for like 10 minutes just roasting

What happened when your teacher made you tutor the star basketball player? My teacher called me to his office and said, you're tutoring Fiona Cove. She needs to pass or she's benched for the season. My first thought, I don't have time for this. Before I could respond, he showed me her test scores on his computer. All C's and D's with the occasional F. She needs someone patient who won't give up on her. You're going to get extra credit, plus a recommendation letter for grad school if you do this. The bribery was working. Fiona was campus royalty. Always surrounded by teammates, always rushing between practice and game. She's desperate to stay on the team. One semester. That's all I'm asking. The offer was too tempting, so I agreed to meet her. Finding her waiting outside the library was surprising. I walked over with my chemistry books. Hey, Fiona. Ready to tackle some chemistry? She looked up, relieved, her practice bag dropping. You actually showed when I nodded. Confused, she explained three tutors had stood her up. They probably figured I was hopeless. The first session, Fiona kept writing down everything I said frantically. Slow down. I need to get this exactly right. I watched her rewrite the same equation four times. It doesn't need to be perfect. She shook her head stubbornly. Yes, it does. I can't lose basketball. We spent three hours on basic periodic table memorization. Fiona made flashcards for every single element. Hydrogen, atomic, Number one, she recited while pacing. Her determination was unexpected. Most people think I'm just here for basketball. She. But I actually want to learn this. The third week we met after her practice at ten PM. Fiona showed up, exhausted but focused. Sorry coach kept us late. Did you eat? She pulled out two sandwiches from her bag. I grabbed extra from the dining hall. We worked through molecular structures while eating. Fiona kept asking questions that showed she was really thinking. Why does oxygen form two bonds but nitrogen forms three? I explained electron shells and watched understanding dawn on her face. That actually makes sense. She high fived me impulsively, then pulled back, embarrassed. Sorry. I get excited. I tried to focus.
